review_text: 2.5 starsThe premise of this book sounded interesting and, even though I couldn't connect to Takako's character, I enjoyed the first part that takes place in the bookshop. I started losing interest in the second part that centers more around her uncle's wife. My main complaint is that I found the writing simplistic and the characters rather flat. There was no depth in their relationships and conversations. Not sure if it's the writing style or the translation. It's not a long book and I listened to it on audio, but it still felt like it took me a long time to get through it. The cover is super cute, though.

It is a touching story about a young woman who discovers the joy of reading.The book is a simple story about books, relationships, family, and community.It is a joyful and easy read, especially for a vacation.I find this book attractive because it is a well-written and engaging story.Generally speaking, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is a charming and enjoyable read.
had me at days in a bookshop(review to come)

I don't know what it is about Japanese translation fiction that always makes me feel peaceful and calm, but Days at the Morisaki Bookshop had that effect. Like Before the Coffee Gets Cold, this short novel with simple prose manages to convey deep truths and impart important life lessons. There's comfort in knowing that bookstores share the same allure across the world. The MC, a young woman named Takako, a sensitive and reserved person, really blossoms by the end of this short book. Many of the literary references were lost on me, but that didn't seem to matter. People connected over books and coffee is a universal joy.

3.5â­â€œHuman beings are full of contradictions.â€Twenty-five-year-old Takako takes up residence for a few months in her uncle Satoruâ€™s second-hand bookshop in Jimbicho, Tokyo in the wake of her breakup with her cad of a boyfriend/ coworker and her subsequent resignation. Depressed and unemployed, Takako is glad for the room above the Morisaki Bookshop to hide from the rest of the world even though she doesnâ€™t quite enjoy reading. Surrounded by towering stacks of second-hand books and people who love reading, Takako eventually finds herself opening up to new experiences, making friends in the community, forging a bond with her uncle and finding joy, inspiration and hope in reading.The narrative is divided into two segments the first of which focuses on Takanoâ€™s journey and the second segment, set a year later, revolves around her uncle and his wife Momoko whose sudden return five years after she left him has him seeking the answers to several unanswered questions. Her auntâ€™s return and their evolving friendship also encourage Takako to reconsider her own priorities.â€œNo matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life. We live our lives trying to find our way.â€Touching upon themes of family, friendship, new beginnings and most importantly the transformative power of books, this is a sweet, simple story that would appeal to book lovers and bibliophiles. I really liked the premise of Days at the Morisaki Bookshop by Satoshi Yagisawa (translated by Eric Ozawa), and loved the descriptions of the Jimbocho Book Town (brought back some fond memories of College Street /â€Boi Paraâ€ of Kolkata, India) and the literary references. The author also references the Kanda Used Book Festival, the largest annual event held in Kanda's Jimbocho secondhand book district that started in 1960. The narrative is evenly paced and compact but I thought the writing (or maybe the translation) was a tad choppy and lacking in depth. Though I didnâ€™t enjoy the second segment of the narrative as much as the first, overall I didn't dislike this short novel in its totality.

Gli autori giapponesi hanno un super potere da non sottovalutare: riescono a descrivere le piÃ¹ semplici azioni quotidiane come se fossero parte di un altro piano esistenziale. Persino leggere un libro sembra un passo per raggiungere lâ€™illuminazione. Il che Ã¨ possibilmente vero se si sceglie quello giusto.Poetica a parte, questo racconto lungo si Ã¨ rivelato una piacevole lettura estiva che coccola lâ€™animo. La trama Ã¨ molto semplice e lineare, senza grandi colpi di scena, ma compensa questa mancanza con uno stile delicato e armonioso.La protagonista Ã¨ Takako, una giovane donna che a causa di problemi di cuore cadrÃ  nellâ€™apatia piÃ¹ totale. Dopo aver lasciato il lavoro, suo zio Satoru la inviterÃ  a passare qualche tempo nella libreria di famiglia per capire cosa fare della sua vita. Dopo una breve esitazione dato che la giovane ha sempre mal visto lâ€™eccentricitÃ  dellâ€™uomo, deciderÃ  comunque di trasferirsi. Dapprima sorpresa dal caratteristico quartiere libresco e dal disordine regnante in casa dello zio, Takako inizierÃ  pian piano a uscire dal proprio guscio con qualche aiuto imprevisto. Non solo, sebbene non sia una grande lettrice, incomincerÃ  ad apprezzare i libri e il lavoro di Satoru sempre di piÃ¹, tanto da aiutarlo a gestire il negozio. Tra clienti abituali, amicizie inaspettate e amori sfuggenti, la placida routine instaurata dai due verrÃ  sconvolta dal ritorno della moglie di Satoru, sparita nel nulla diversi anni prima. La donna porterÃ  con sÃ© molte domande e segreti, segreti che Takako Ã¨ decisa a scoprire.Sebbene abbia preferito la prima parte, ovvero quella dedicata ai libri, lâ€™insieme si sposa bene nella tipica placiditÃ  orientale. E ora so persino in quale quartiere di Tokyo alloggiare.

You know that feeling when you read a book and it's an international bestseller they made into a film and you're like "but this slid out of my brain like it was greased and nothing happens except a vague feeling of melancholy and what the hell is there even to film?" That. Fine. I don't see anything in this that you couldn't get out of the ~4000 other books about a sad person regaining enjoyment of life via a bookshop, but what do I know, I'm not the international bestseller here. Nice line about the sun glaring like a teenage boy. The cover of the print edition is outstandingly beautiful.

De entrada se nos antojaba que â€œMis dÃ­as en la librerÃ­a Morisakiâ€ iba a ser este tipo de libro confortable, que a mÃ­ me gusta comparar con dar un paseo por un lugar agradable, del que siempre sales reconfortado, y aunque es totalmente ese tipo de libro, ambos tuvimos la misma sensaciÃ³n sobre Ã©l: libro bonito y tierno muy disfrutable, pero que nos hubiese gustado que fuera mÃ¡s largo, para que fuera mÃ¡s reposado y poder indagar algo mÃ¡s en algunos momentos y personajes. Se nos hizo demasiado breve y alguna trama se queda poco explorada.El libro se divide en dos partes muy diferenciadas y claramente la primera parte con Takako y Satoru en la librerÃ­a ha sido mi favorita, y me ha gustado bastante mÃ¡s que la segunda, que podrÃ­a ser mÃ¡s profunda que la primera, pero me ha dejado con ganas de ver mÃ¡s. Lo que sÃ­ he disfrutado mucho ha sido la relaciÃ³n que se forja entre Takako y Wada, un personaje que aparece en esta segunda parte, aunque tambiÃ©n me hubiera gustado verla mÃ¡s mostradaEso sÃ­, disfruto mucho de la habilidad de los japoneses no solo para crear historias agradables y reconfortantes, si no para ubicarlas en escenarios que sin haber visto en tu vida, te resultan familiares, hogareÃ±os, lugares en los que sientes que has estado, aunque nunca los hayas visitado. Satoshi Yagisawaâ€™s debut novel, first published in 2010, won the Chiyoda Literature Prize and was later turned into a film. Itâ€™ s a gentle, slice-of-life narrative set in JimbÅchÅ, the district of Tokyo famous for its array of second-hand bookshops. After a disastrous end to a relationship Takako is drifting and melancholy, she leaves her job and reluctantly moves into a small room over her uncleâ€™s bookshop. Yagisawaâ€™s novel details Takakoâ€™s journey as she finds solace in reading and the small pleasures offered by the local community: from eccentric customers to charming coffee shops. The story then skips ahead over a period of years, moving from Takako to her uncle Satoru as heâ€™s reunited with his long-lost wife Momoko, after her mysterious disappearance. This is oddly fragmented, sometimes a little uneven, and the translation could be smoother but I enjoyed its quirky feel and the emphasis on the transformative power of reading. Translated by Eric Ozawa.Thanks to Edelweiss and publisher HarperCollins for an ARCRating: 3 to 3.5

Mis dÃ­as en la librerÃ­a Morisaki es una obra cÃ¡lida que harÃ¡ disfrutar al pÃºblico lector al que le apasionan las historias serenas, introspectivas, que se cocinan a fuego lento. I usually avoid books set in bookstores and libraries because they tend to be too sentimental for my tastes (How Can I Help YouÂ being a delicious exception).Â This book, unfortunately, is not an exception. It's all feelings and even worse, blekky romantic feelings as well. All heterosexual too, which makes it even less of an interest to me, if possible.Â I'm the Tin Man before Dorothy, no heart. This kind of stuff annoys me.Two positives: it was short, and there's an adorable cat on the cover - perhaps I'd have liked the book more if the cat had been part of it.

An ode to rediscovering the love for reading and the transformative power of entering the realm of books. Heartwarming, well done portrait of the importance of candor and speaking out, especially when its difficult.If I just told them what they wanted to hear that wouldnâ€™t fix anything.A sweet trip to secondhand bookstores and the mountains, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop feels like a nice excursion from corporate life. Our main character, a 25 year old office worker, has her life fall apart during a fancy dinner, and turns into a sleep monster. With the help of an uncle and literature she finds a place in the world again. Maybe it takes a long time to figure out what you are truly searching for. Maybe you spend your whole life just to figure out a small part of it.The district full of specialised bookstores sounds lovely, as sound of a back-up plan and the best taking a vacation of oneâ€™s life one can find!But our main character canâ€™t escape hard things, she needs to push through them to truly find herself and shed the societal pressure of always being a good girl:This is might be the first time in my life I raised my voice and told another person how I felt - no wonder mental health is such a theme in Japanese literature.Peoples impressions arenâ€™t very reliable are they? is something that comes back a lot in the second part, when the main character can return the favor to her uncle. Very much a slice of life book, wholesome and restorative for anyone who feels low in their trust in the world and people.

This book is without a doubt, a truly heartwarming read. It envelops you in its warmth like a cherished, old sweater, making it feel like a literary hug. At its core, this book is a celebration of the transformative power of literature, how books can quietly but profoundly alter the course of our lives. It's a wholesome, sweet, and comforting story that will undoubtedly leave a lasting imprint on your heart. From that moment on, I read relentlessly, one book after another. It was as if a love of reading had been sleeping somewhere deep inside me all this time, and then it suddenly sprang to life.   Little by little, I felt something wash over me, a feeling of peace that words can't express. If I had to explain it, I'd say it could only have come from the writer's fervent love for life. The story revolves around a small, second-hand bookshop, Morisaki Bookshop, and the wonderful cast of characters who call it home. The narrative centers on Takako, whose life takes a transformative turn following a heartbreak when she retreats to her family's bookstore, managed by her uncle Saturo. As the characters navigate the ups and downs of life, their journeys are intertwined with the books they read and recommend, resulting in a brilliant tapestry of self-discovery. At some point in the past, someone reading this book had felt moved to take a pen and draw a line under these words. It made me happy to think that because I had been moved by that same passage too, I was now connected to that stranger.Another time, I happened to find a pressed flower someone had left as a bookmark. As I inhaled the scent of the long-ago-faded flower, I wondered about the person who had put it there. Who in the world was she? When did she live? What was she feeling?It's only in secondhand books that you can savor encounters like this, connections that transcend time. And that's how I learned to love the secondhand bookstore that handled these books, our Morisaki Bookshop. I realized how precious a chance I'd been given, to be a part of that little place, where you can feel the quiet flow of time.  The prose is simple yet eloquent, like a soothing melody that lingers in your mind long after you've turned the last page.

Una pequeÃ±a y antigua librerÃ­a en JapÃ³n, situada en el barrio mÃ¡s literario del mundo. Un lugar de paz, donde el tiempo parece detenerse y suceden conversaciones cultas e interesantes sobre literatura japonesa entre personajes inolvidables. Â¿QuÃ© podrÃ­a ir mal ante semejante caramelito para los amantes de la literatura sobre librerÃ­as?Eso es lo que la premisa de este tÃ­tulo nos avanza en su contraportada, otra cosa es lo que los lectores encontraremos. No os engaÃ±arÃ©, esta lectura ha sido la peor que he tenido en los Ãºltimos meses. Algo que obviamente no esperaba, ya que a pesar de saber que no iba a ser un libro inolvidable tenÃ­a el convencimiento de que encontrarÃ­a una historia â€œfeel goodâ€, algo agradable y ligero para disfrutar.Nada mÃ¡s lejos de la realidad: entre sus pÃ¡ginas he hallado una trama lineal, sumamente bÃ¡sica y carente de descripciÃ³n alguna, dotada de personajes planos, sin carÃ¡cter definido y sumamente incoherentes (menciÃ³n especial a la protagonista que no puede ser mÃ¡s repelente). La trama, aparte de previsible, en muchas ocasiones pierde el sentido, fuerza relaciones y sentimientos que no traspasan las pÃ¡ginas y no convencen en absoluto al lector.Eso no es todo: aquÃ­ no hay literatura, ni cultura japonesa, ni librerÃ­as, ni largas charlas emocionantes, ni puesta en situaciÃ³nâ€¦ La novela bien podrÃ­a estar ambientada en una heladerÃ­a de un centro comercial en Estados Unidos y no notarÃ­amos la diferencia. La narraciÃ³n, los diÃ¡logos y cÃ³mo se desarrollan los hechos, denota que estamos ante un relato banal, por su sencillez y por la escasa profundidad general.En definitiva, me he llevado una gran decepciÃ³n con esta obra contando que lo mejor que he encontrado es la ilustraciÃ³n de la portada. Y encima, no podÃ­a faltar el drama metido con calzador que encontraremos al final y el nacimiento de un amor que no veÃ­amos venir (nÃ³tese la ironÃ­a). Book lovers are delighted when the plot of the story includes books or bookstores or an authorâ€™s life. This book was indeed that and much more. Sensitive topics like dealing with heartbreak, boredom, loneliness were handled so well and again it was not that it was being preachy. I liked the characters and the description of Jimbocho area where second hand books were sold in so many bookshops was readerâ€™s delight. The support that Takako got from her uncle and her journey of healing by diving into books and through her auntâ€™s lifestyle was heart warming. I really enjoyed reading this translated work and glad that I picked up.
books about books will always be my favorite!
Basically a story of finding yourself amid rows and rows of secondhand books. Story of love, loss and reconciliation.

It gently eased my soul.

Enjoyable and gentle book that centers around Satoru the owner of the Morisaki Bookshop, along with his niece, Takako, and Satoru's absent wife, Momoko. As Takato suffers from a broken relationshp her uncle Satoru offers her a chance to come live and work at the bookshop. After a period of continued despair she finally comes to love the bookshop and a few of the people who enter. Not a book that goes into detail about the books at the used bookshop, but rather about relationships, including Momoko's return after a 5 year absence. I enjoyed the book but felt it needed a bit more depth to the characters and more characters on the whole. I did enjoy it and there is only so much one can fit into 150 pages. I am looking forward to the sequel. As I am not familiar with a lot of Japanese novels I give this a benefit of the doubt, 4****

3.5*O livro lÃª-se bem, mas faltou ali qualquer coisa - profundidade, creio. Sendo um livro tÃ£o pequeno, Ã© natural que a histÃ³ria nÃ£o seja incrivelmente bem explorada, mas haveria espaÃ§o para o fazer, porque as temÃ¡ticas sÃ£o interessantes.

Takako is 25 years old and just got dumped. When she finds out her boyfriend has been seeing someone else at their work and is engaged to get married to her next year, her life goes into a tailspin. She's depressed, lonely and after quitting her job, a bit aimless. One day her Uncle Satoru calls her. He runs the family used bookstore in JimbÅchÅ, the book shop district in Tokyo. He could use her help, and with nothing else going on, she finally caves and goes to see what she can make of her life there.This is a super sweet, simple story about rediscovering oneself, falling in love with books, and the many ways we can connect with other people when we take a second to get to know them on a bit of a deeper level. Takako comes into her new job with many presumptions that get subverted, and along with loyal customers to the bookstore and people she meets at a local coffee shop, she begins to see things a little differently.There's only a small plot in this slim novel, and ultimately it's more about the vibes and atmosphere of the bookshop which is rendered wonderfully; that's the part I loved most about this bookâ€”the sights and smells of the neighborhood came to life off the page. Takako is a likeable main character to follow and goes on her own journey across the book's two parts, realizing in life there's often more than meets the eye. I did want a bit more depth to the story, but for what it was this was a highly enjoyable comforting read that I'd recommend to book lovers everywhere.[Thank you to the publisher for an advanced reader's copy for review. All thoughts and opinions are my own.]

Era da tanto che volevo leggere questo libro e finalmente ci sono riuscita. Protagonista di questo racconto di questa storia delicata Ã¨ la giovane Takako, che da un giorno allâ€™altro viene travolta dalla notizia del suo fidanzato che le comunica di sposarsi. Ma con unâ€™altra. Questo Ã¨ lâ€™esordiente per far risolvere Takako a far visita allo zio Satoru, proprietario di una libreria. â€œAbitavo sommersa dai libri in una stanza al primo piano, un ambiente buio e angusto, umido, pervaso dellâ€™odore di muffa tipico della carta vecchia.CiÃ² nonostante, il ricordo di quelle giornate Ã¨ ormai parte di me perchÃ© Ã¨ proprio lÃ¬ che la mia vita, la mia vera vita, Ã¨ cominciata. Senza quellâ€™esperienza tutto sarebbe stato molto piÃ¹ scialbo, banale, piatto.â€Quelle pile di libri aiutano Takako a scoprire la sua vera essenza: bello anche leggere tanti nomi che sono pilastri della letteratura giapponese. E mentre i libri aiutano Takako a ritrovare e scoprire la vera sÃ© stessa, allo stesso modo Satoru riuscirÃ  a ricucire le sue ferite, grazie proprio alla presenza della nipote. â€œLa libreria Morisaki si trova allâ€™angolo di una strada piena di librerie dellâ€™usato. Ãˆ piccola, vecchia, e non sembra che gli affari vadano troppo bene. Di clienti se ne vedono pochi. Tratta una varietÃ  piuttosto limitata di libri e, a meno di essere degli esperti appassionati, Ã¨ difficile che la si conosca.Eppure câ€™Ã¨ chi ama questo posto. Lo zio Satoru dice sempre che lâ€™amore di queste persone per lui Ã¨ piÃ¹ che sufficiente, e questo mi piace. CosÃ¬ come mi piace lui, il proprietario della libreria Morisaki.â€Una storia di legami duraturi, di amore, di smarrimenti e di ricongiungimenti. Una storia tra i libri, dove i libri custodiscono le chiavi per risolvere e dare un senso alla propria vita.

Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is a short (thankfully) corny (unbearably so) novel about a heartbroken 25-year-old woman who is able to heal and find new meaning in life by working at her uncle's second-hand bookshop. Takako, our central character, is no longer able to keep working at her company after her supposed boyfriend informs her, very casually, that he is actually going to marry someone else. She's thrown off kilter and soon finds it impossible to keep on working. More depressed than ever, Takako's days of listlessness are interrupted by a call from her eccentric uncle, whom she hadn't kept in contact with. He offers her a place to stay, rent-free, in exchange for helping out at his second-hand bookshop. She reluctantly agrees, but to begin with, has no interest in the place or its contents. Eventually, she learns to love literature and the bookshop, breaking free of her post-breakup apathy. Turns out her uncle is a nice guy and so is that cantankerous regular customer! Good times ensue and Takako not only gets better but learns valuable life lessons along the way. And I guess this could have just been a Hallmark-y, inoffensive, vanilla book about learning to love books and unexpected friendships and not judging people based on first impressions but we get a whole storyline involving Takako's aunt that veered straight into the mawkish. Worst, her story is moralistic, and punitive even, as we learn that the aunt left Takako's uncle because they are unable to conceive, a fact that the narrative implies to be a consequence of her having had an abortion. So now of course she blames herself...but 'confessing' this to Takako helps her to begin forgiving herself.... I'm afraid that the way this issue is handled, as well as the platitudes that come to the surface during the conversations between the aunt & Takako, came across as clichÃ©d, icky even. Needless to say, I was unsurprised to see that this book had been written by a man. As with any other review of mine, I feel the need to remind whoever is reading this that what they have just read is entirely subjective and that my not liking a book should not stop you from giving it a try.

I received a copy of this book for free from the publisher (Harper Perennial) for promotional purposes. At just under 150 pages, this book was short but still so powerful!The book is separated into 2 parts. The first part focuses on the main character, Takako, and her life working at the bookshop, which I found very charming and cute. If youâ€™re a bookworm and a bibliophile, this part will definitely resonate with you! The second part focuses on the Takakoâ€™s relationships with others. This part was more emotional. I enjoyed both parts because they each offered something different. Some may find the simplicity of the story hard to connect with, but it worked for me. There was something really beautiful and understated about it. This is a translated Japanese story, so it can feel quite different from an American novel. I also loved learning about Jimbocho, Japanâ€™s book district (where the story takes place). I never knew this place existed but it sounds amazing. Since this is a book about books, I have to share a quote I loved about the magic of secondhand books. Takako ponders, â€œI happened to find a pressed flower someone had left as a bookmark. As I inhaled the scent of the long-ago-faded flower, I wondered about the person who had put it there. Who in the world was she? When did she live? What was she feeling? Itâ€™s only in secondhand books that you can savor encounters like this, connections that transcend timeâ€ (pg. 37). I couldnâ€™t agree more! Overall, this was a gem of a book! If youâ€™re looking for something quick and a little different to read, consider picking this one up.

I was drawn to this story initially because of the bookish premise. After twenty five year old Takako loses her boyfriend and her job in the span of a day, she has nowhere else to turn â€” so when her uncle Satoru invites her to stay in a room above his Morisaki bookshop in exchange for helping him watch the shop several hours a day, Takako agrees, even though she has never been a reader and has no interest in books. When she arrives at the location of her familyâ€™s bookshop in Jimbocho, she finds that the area is actually a book loverâ€™s paradise where â€œeverywhere you turned, there was another bookshop.â€ At the Morisaki bookshop, Takako is (literally) surrounded by books day and night â€” not surprisingly, she also encounters various people who love to read. Pretty soon, Takako experiences for herself the healing power of books, but more significantly, her stay at the bookshop ends up changing her life in ways she never thought possible.This was a simple, quiet story filled with eccentric yet endearing characters that you couldnâ€™t help but love â€” for me, these were the main strengths of the book. Unfortunately, the execution didnâ€™t quite work for me, as the writing felt choppy and stilted, with some sections sounding really awkward to read. The pacing also felt off, with the two parts that the story was divided into feeling like two different books, which kind of threw me off a bit. Iâ€™m not sure if something was lost in translation or the original work was written this way, but I just felt like there was more potential to the story than was tapped into. And I must admit that I was a tad disappointed with the second half of the story veering away from the bookish aspects that played such a huge role in the first half.Overall, this was an â€œokayâ€ read. I enjoyed some aspects over others and definitely felt the first half of the story was much stronger. This is an instance where I wish I knew Japanese so I could check out the original work and see if the experience would be different. Ah well, thatâ€™s how things go, I guess.Received ARC from Harper Perennial via NetGalley.

â€œItâ€™s funny. No matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life.â€  "I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki" Ã¨ un libro semplice, senza pretese.Siamo a Tokyo, precisamente a JinbÅchÅ, il quartiere delle librerie, dove ogni vetrina Ã¨ stipata allâ€™inverosimile di libri, nuovi o di seconda mano. La venticinquenne Tatako non Ã¨ una grande frequentatrice del quartiere, nÃ© unaÂ  lettrice forte. Eppure, quando all'improvviso si troverÃ  sola e senza lavoro, sarÃ  suo zio Satoru a lanciarle unâ€™ancora di salvezza, offrendole di trasferirsi al primo piano della libreria Morisaki, che appartiene alla sua famiglia da tre generazioni. LÃ¬, Tatako scoprirÃ  il piacere della tranquillitÃ  e l'amore per la letteratura, e saranno proprio i libri a guidarla verso un meraviglioso percorso di crescita.Indubbiamente, questo libro Ã¨ un elogio al potere salvifico della lettura; una lettera d'amore alle piccole librerie, custodi di un sapere infinito in pochissimi metri quadri; un'ode alle piccole cose e ai piaceri di una vita tranquilla.Come dicevo, "I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki" Ã¨ un libro senza pretese - forse un po' troppo senza pretese. Se la prima metÃ  Ã¨ abbastanza interessante, la seconda - che si concentra di piÃ¹ sulla figura della moglie dello zio Satoru - mi ha fatto lentamente scivolare in un irritante stato di noia, tanto da far quasi sbiadire la bellezza dei primi capitoli.Insomma, sebbene la delicatezza della narrazione sia inequivocabile, non posso dire di esserne stata completamente conquistata.Â 3 stelle (anche se un po' scarsette) e menzione speciale all'audiolibro, letto veramente bene.Â

This book could have been much more. So much more. So much wasted potential ğŸ˜’ğŸ˜‘The book revolves around a heartbroken Takako and her equally heartbroken uncle, who owns a second-hand bookstore ğŸ“š. While the book is not exactly a romance novel, romance is the raison dâ€™etre of all (or most) characters. I do not know if this is the reason behind most characters' self-absorbed, selfish behavior and others' self-depreciation and (unfounded) guilt. Regardless, the characters lack depth, even in the most serious moments. And the books -- what about the books? They were a conduit for characters to move on from heartbreaks and/or meet new lovers, but they could have been candies or socks for how little their content mattered ğŸ¥².On top of that (and here I am getting personal): I am close to my parents and brother, but I have never been very close to my aunts and uncles. Sure, I am on good terms with them, but nowhere near the relationships described in the book. I felt so uncomfortable with how pushy Momoko was (like running-away-kind-of uncomfortable ğŸƒğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸).Finally:ğŸ˜¡ why put a cat on the cover if cats are never mentioned in the book? 3.5 StarsI was drawn to this book by virtue of its being translated from the Japanese. I love Asian influenced books for their spare, simple, frank writing styles. The book began with the plight of a young woman living by herself, having moved away from her parents in Tokyo. Her life blows up when the guy she's dating at work turns out to be engaged to another employee. Her existence at the job becomes untenable in light of this relationship disaster, so she resigns. An eccentric uncle who she hasn't seen in a decade suddenly calls to offer her a lifeline, which she accepts: to join him at his secondhand book shop where she can live and work, and just figure out life. This part of the book was my favorite. She came to know the little bustling streets which housed many secondhand bookshops and their clientele, a unique, enticing neighborhood coffee shop, and a new, awe-inspiring love of reading she never had before. While the story moved forward in a quiet way that I normally love, the final quarter of the book began to lose me rather than win me over. Thank you to the publisher Harper Perennial for providing an advance reader copy via NetGalley.
Blander than water, slower than snail.

I didn't like the book. I needed something light and I thought this would be a great choice, but in my opinion it lacks content, alignment and robustness. I didn't get the depth of the relationships, meaning some conversations/reactions didn't make sense to me. I get that this is a tiny book, but still - "The Notebook" is a tiny book and there is involvement and depth. I didn't get the message it was trying to pass, like how have the books changed her? What was the actual impact?Maybe I completely missed the point, but I wasn't entertained. I was expecting a good short story, with a nice message, but it just felt like a bunch of events that had nothing to do with the characters' development.Despite that, I have to say that the book's cover is soooooo beautiful!!! Gorgeous, that I loved!

3.5/5 An extremely comforting and healing story about Makako who visits her uncle and decides to stay back at his bookshop. Tired and mourning over the separation of her partner, she decides to take shelter at his place. The part 1 was straight out of a drama - full of rediscovering the little joys, the benefits of living at a reader's place, the popular Japanese authors and their works - some of which I'm familiar with. I found this part to be more dearer as the latter deals with stuff her uncle's life. I found a deep solace in reading about Makako as she embodies every other twenty something woman.

Una storia semplice ma dolcissima, che accarezza lâ€™anima. PuÃ² essere molto confortevole se letta nel momento giusto. Ho preferito la prima metÃ  del libro alla seconda e avrei voluto che fosse piÃ¹ lungo.

In short: A twenty-something girlâ€™s heart is broken when her boyfriend of a year tells her heâ€™s getting married (to her co-worker). She flees to another town and goes to work for her bookstore-owning uncle, in exchange for room and board. Uncle has a broken heart, as well, so the two commiserate and become close. In the end,  everything works out beautifully (like a fairytale) and everyone is happy.It seemed pretty lame and immature to me. In the early stages of the book, I actually felt quite embarrassed for the author. To be fair, thoughâ€”and unless I learn Japanese Iâ€™ll never knowâ€”the translation may have been at least partly to blame. It was simply puerile. If Iâ€™d read the book when I was a child, I might have described the main character as something of a â€œGoody-Two-Shoesâ€.ğŸ¤­ Itâ€™s also possible that cultural differences may be at play here. But, more so, IMHO it would be more appropriate for the Young Adult market, and I feel like that audience would be much more accepting of the story. 2 â€œIt-was-just-okayâ€ stars â­â­

Deliziosa favola consolatoria in stile giapponese. Non pensavo fosse una popolazione cosÃ¬ sentimentale!!! Libro "ruffiano" come dico io: parla di libri e questo per noi lettori Ã¨ un assist a cui non sappiamo resistere.Cominciai a piangere, e piÃ¹ piangevo, piÃ¹ mi veniva da piangere. Singhiozzavo in mezzo alla stanza, non accesi nemmeno la luce. Anzi, forse lo si capisce a poco a poco, e ci vuole una vita intera.â€â€œIo... Significa trasferire su un oggetto parte della nostra anima, se non la sua totalitÃ .Lo zio mi guardÃ² e sorrise dolcemente. â€œNo, non credo. A volte bisogna anche fermarsi. How does one move past their old grievances?
Takako believes that her decision to visit the Morisaki bookstore and explore the world of books was the best one she has ever made. Satoru sees healing as a second shot at love with his ex-wife. A warm and cozy read about love and healing in which both Takako and Satoru discovers that their days spent together in the bookstore would nurture empathy, understanding, and compassion in them. This was one of the books I am highly anticipating since last year and while I did get the message the author wants to tell in this book, I found the dynamics of the characters as well as their conversations with each other lacking. Sometimes reading the story felt flat because the characters are too one-dimensional. Moreover, the first part had so much potential but during the second part, it made no sense to me because I think the story centered at Momoko way too much. I needed more interactions between Satoru and Takako; especially Takakoâ€™s character growth and development. Overall, I think it would be a 2.5 or 3 stars for me. I found this an easy and brief read to kill time. The story could have more potential, though.

Rating: a generous 4* of fiveThe Publisher Says: The moving international sensation about new beginnings, human connection, and the joy of reading.Hidden in Jimbocho, Tokyo, is a booklover's paradise. On a quiet corner in an old wooden building lies a shop filled with hundreds of second-hand books.Twenty-five-year-old Takako has never liked reading, although the Morisaki bookshop has been in her family for three generations. It is the pride and joy of her uncle Satoru, who has devoted his life to the bookshop since his wife Momoko left him five years earlier.When Takako's boyfriend reveals he's marrying someone else, she reluctantly accepts her eccentric uncle's offer to live rent-free in the tiny room above the shop. Hoping to nurse her broken heart in peace, Takako is surprised to encounter new worlds within the stacks of books lining the Morisaki bookshop.As summer fades to autumn, Satoru and Takako discover they have more in common than they first thought. The Morisaki bookshop has something to teach them both about life, love, and the healing power of books.I RECEIVED A DRC FROM THE PUBLISHER VIA NETGALLEY. THANK YOU.My Review: A book about books, and a bookshop, and the gentle art of connecting to others in the broken places life inflicts on us? A non-reader learning the power of books, and stories, to help and heal and bring us together? Sign me up!You get all of that in this internationally bestselling novel. It is exactly correctly marketed, and aimed directly at the book-gollum that lurks in your #Booksgiving circle...the mid-teens niece who gobbles the usual suspects of YA fiction, the later tween granddaughter who needs a fresh subject to care passionately about. The reader who is also a bookaholic is likely to get less from it than a newer reader, as this is largely well-traveled territory for most of us over a certain age; still enjoyable, certainly, and so short that it's a long sitting of reading.I've just been here before quite often. Moods and atmosphere make for fun experiences of reading and Jimbocho, in a few deft strokes feels real. Why then am I recommending it for your teen bookeaters? It's...fine. It's not more than fine, but it's solidly...fine. I reserve phrases like "good enough" to damn with faint praise. This is..fine. Sitting around with one's less than riveting relatives of a Yuletide eve, this is the best kind of read to have, and so to give to someone who's in that situation.Coping with heartbreak is always going to appeal to younger audiences. They experience so much of it. The nature of Takako's dumping by her pretty rotten boyfriend is going to appeal; the nature of Satoru and Motoko's estrangement will certainly raise a lot of tissues.Finding Family within one's family is a rare and wonderful experience. I think the story is a hit around the world for a very clear reason. Get it into the right hands and it will make the Yuletide bright, shiny, and bearable.

â€œDonâ€™t be afraid to love someone.When you fall in love, I want you to fall in love all the way. Even if it ends in heartache, please donâ€™t live a lonely life without love.â€ ..When you feel that life has failed you and that you have made many wrong decisions in your life, you decide to isolate yourself alone in your apartment.The best way to help yourself and get rid of all these negative feelings is to spend your time with books.And that is exactly what happened to our friend "Takano". After she quit her job because of her lover's betrayal, her uncle "Satoru" â™¥ called her to help him take care of his bookstore, in an attempt to help her get through this difficult stage in her life...There is nothing more beautiful than reading books, except reading books that talk about books.What an amazing journey I had with this book, The only flaw about it is that it ends so quickly.I felt that there was a wave of friendly and intimate feelings, taking me away from everything bad in my life, and transporting me to a beautiful and kind world. The characters were adorable, the plot was peaceful, and the narration was as delightful and loveable as possible.I loved everything about this book, and I felt from the first pages that this book would be one of my favorites, and it was.This book is perfect for everyone who loves books. I advise everyone to read it. It is truly a magical book, despite the simplicity of the story, but it will fill your life with everything you need. ..â€œMaybe it takes a long time to figure out what you're truly searching for. Maybe you spend your whole life just to figure out a small part of it."
An enjoyable debut novel which I didnâ€™t want to end! Will definitely read the sequel More Days at the Morisaki Bookshop.

Translated from Japanese, Days At The Morisaki Bookshop was charming, warm hug of a book that I really enjoyed. Though itâ€™s only 160 pages long, it managed to pack a rather powerful punch thanks to itâ€™s slice-of-life style narrative, endearing characters and tender exploration of family, reconnection, and the therapeutic power of booksâ€” and perfect for settling down with on a chilly autumn evening. It follows a young woman, Takako who moves into her uncleâ€™s secondhand bookshop, after quitting her job and spiralling into depression from the devastating news of her boyfriendâ€™s betrayal and subsequent engagement. But with an uncle like Satoru, whoâ€™s childlike enthusiasm for both books and the community he calls home, Takako slowly begins to get back on track â€”making new friends and rediscovering the joy of life through books, the empathy they inspire and the bookish people who love them.This is the perfect read for bibliophiles who love quick, cosy stories that celebrate the importance of connectionâ€”and most importantly, the almost life changing feeling of discovering a good book.The addictively soothing style of writing was soo incredibly enjoyable, which I have credit to translator Eric Ozawa for , as he brought Satoshi Yagisawaâ€™s brilliant story to life soo beautifully, which isnâ€™t always the case for a lot of translated works. The descriptions of Jimbocho were quite vivid, and the characters we meet there (like notable fave, Sabu) were rather delightful in their quirkiness. Overall, this was a fun, heartfelt and entertaining read that has me eager to get my hands on an English translation of the sequel. Though, do check content warnings as it does touch upon sensitive topics such as infertility, miscarriage and terminal illness.Also, a massive thank you to Abigail Walton and Bonnier Books for the finished copy.

3.5 â­ï¸ Itâ€™s a short book, but I took my time reading it. It filled me with a feeling that I had forgotten. I recalled the time I started reading for the first time and how I was engrossed with it. I resonate with the story of this book. All the characters were adorable, a bit silly and childlike, but kind and funny, nonetheless. It shows you how thereâ€™s always more to the story and sometimes, you just have to be patient.I really wish I had a relative who ran a bookstore and I could go and visit them from time to time. There are times that I also need a little vocation. I wouldnâ€™t have minded if I lived like Takako. Iâ€™ll write down some of my favourite quotes soon.

A tale of family, reconnection, home and what it means to love books!Days at the Morisaki Bookshop was wholesome and heartwarming. Narrating the experience of 25 year old Takako and the complexities of her romantic relationship and thus heartbreak - we follow her reignite her relationship with her uncle and the bookshop that has been in her family for 3 generations. I initially ADORED this. As not only a book lover but also a bookseller, I absolutely loved the ambience of the bookshop and its descriptions. However, this book doesn't really have space to allow any emotional connection to its characters. Although I definitely felt the pull of my heartstrings when it came to the family element, the characters all felt fairly two dimensional and I struggled understanding some of their actions. I so wish that each of them was explored more individually!This is one that I will still absolutely recommend though. If you're looking to get into translated fiction, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is undoubtedly one accessible for beginners and equally to those who already admire the genre!

This is a terrible book: trite and self-congratulatory. It is possible that the translation by Eric Ozawa compounds the miserable prose, but the plot suggests a lack of imagination which could well be as bad as the hackneyed style. Going up to bed shouldnâ€™t need three tries at describing arriving in the room, and real people do not have conversations peppered with superfluous adjectives: â€œthe cheerful booksellerâ€ only requires the qualification if you are differentiating between booksellers, whereas this is an attempt to add flavour, an attempt that falls noticeably flat. The best thing about this book is the cover illustration.

"Un patio de recreo para los amantes de los libros"Un libro ideal para los amantes de los libros, que nos envuelve en una historia familiar, de decepciones amorosas, reencuentros, nuevas amistades y nuevas oportunidades que se van presentando gracias a los libros y su particular magia.Una invitaciÃ³n a redescubrirnos y a reflexionar sobre lo que queremos de la vida, a travÃ©s de una historiaÂ sencilla y cotidiana pero que te carga de una sensaciÃ³n de profunda paz y tranquilidad.La primera parte fue mi favorita y el final no fue del todo de mi agrado, lo sentÃ­ un poco abrupto, pero en general fue un libro muy relajante y rÃ¡pido de leer que hace que te den ganas de viajar a este barrio lleno de librerÃ­as con su ambiente tan particular.Les dejo aquÃ­ algunas frases destacadas:"No siempre es fÃ¡cil entender lo que se quiere de la vida. De hecho, entenderlo lleva toda la vida.""Las circunstancias inesperadas nos abren puertas que no podrÃ­amos imaginar."

Devo ancora riflettere su ciÃ² che ho pensato di questo libro.Per ora posso dirvi che ho apprezzato lo stile scorrevole e la sua brevitÃ  in generale.La prima parte del libro Ã¨ quella che ho preferito, anche perchÃ© rispecchia appieno il titolo del romanzo (anche se non ho modo di verificare se sia letterale o no).Non ho trovato esattamente quello che pensavo di trovare da questo titolo, ovvero una storia molto legata al mondo dei libri (se non per la parte iniziale).Ho sottolineato alcune frasi molto carine, e mi Ã¨ piaciuto il rapporto fra la nostra protagonista e suo zio.Speravo mi rubasse il cuore.

A inceput cu foarte mult potential, despre alienare, singuratatea de dupa o relatie si burnout si chiar parea genul de carte pe care o puteam termina intr-o zi.Cu timpul, a inceput sa fie din ce in ce mai superficial scrisa, dar si asa parea enjoyable, pana sa apara personajul Momoko, care sa genereze o drama ieftina, care din punctul meu de vedere nu isi avea locul.Sfarsitul, din nou, nu mi-a placut ca a fost ca din pom, dar o sa ii dau doua stele pentru potentialul pe care l-ar fi putut avea

Questo libro promette e mantiene: atmosfere giapponesi delicate ma pervasive, quella ritrosia nellâ€™eccedere nei sentimenti senza perÃ² privarne la storia, personaggi con una nota indolente di fondo che infine trovano la loro strada, o fanno pace col passato.Ãˆ un libro breve e scritto con semplicitÃ , tipico di una certa narrativa jap, ma che mi ha fatto molta compagnia e che consiglierÃ² a chi cerca qualcosa di leggero ma altamente piacevole.

A charming story set in a bookshop in Jinbocho, the district known for it's many bookshops in Tokyo. Why had I never heard that there was a bookshop district in Tokyo before? I believe it's the first in a series. I hope that the second book is released in English sooner rather than later. A few Japanese novels are read by the characters in the book, I've noted the titles to see if they are translated to English and are locally available.

Ambientazione molto carina, ma la trama e i personaggi sono scontati e, a tratti, infantili.

A gentle little tale, simply told.

I thought this was a charming, lovely book. Probably 4 stars is a little too generous but I felt that 3 stars didn't convey how much I enjoyed reading thisTakako is heartbroken when she finds out her boyfriend is cheating on her and goes into a prolonged slump. They work in the same office so that becomes unbearable for her and she leaves her job. Now she does nothing but sleep all day.Her uncle, about whom she is, to say the least, ambivalent, invites her to stay with her--living in a room above his bookstore in exchange for helping him out a little. She agrees--not because she especially wants to but because she can't go on as she has been, if for no other reason than she is running out of money.That's the premise and the story unfolds from there--relationships and books (and coffee). Three of my most favorite topics.Enjoy!
Ã© um livro muito bom, mas o meio pro final Ã© bem chato

It was such a charming and cozy narrative to me and I like how the theme centered around a lifestyle and day-to-day plot that delved intricately on self-healing and family relationships. From a grief and depression after a heartbreak and losing her job, Takako suddenly gets a call from her distant Uncle Satoru asking if she can help him out at his secondhand bookshop that was located in the famous book district of Jimbocho. With an offer of a rent-free place to stay and thinking it might be temporary until she can get back on her feet again; it was not a bad idea afterall. So all packed up for Takako and her days at Morisaki Bookshop begins. A light and pleasant narrative that goes quite appealingly narrated. The unexpected journey of finding solace in an old classic bookshop and to find the love in both reading and books againâ€” so stirring and I love how Takakoâ€™s perspective felt so close and somehow relatable; her bookish refs were helpful much (think I need to start reading Osamu Dazai soon!) and her musings too although at times her emotional rants can be too sentimental yet I enjoyed her healing quest through her interaction with Satoru and her new found friendship after working at the bookshop. Thanks to her too that I get to tour the other secondhand bookshops around the district! Part 2 was quite melodramatic as it revolves mostly on Satoruâ€™s relationship conflict and drama; quite uplifting for me to explore Aunt Momokoâ€™s narrative and to see the lovable and heartwarming interactions in between Takako and her aunt. Fairly executed dynamic for Takakoâ€™s character, not really fancy with Wada but their scenes did add more charms at the end. Would recommend if you like a slice-of-life genre on family and self-healing plot as well for the startling bookish setting! Thank you Pansing Distribution for the gifted review copy!

Desde la primera pÃ¡gina hasta la Ãºltima la historia estÃ¡ impregnada de una atmÃ³sfera reconfortante que abraza al lector y ofrece esa sensaciÃ³n que solemos definir como de estar en casa. La prosa es sencilla y amena, lo que hace que el libro se lea solo y sin darte cuenta llegues al final con una sonrisa en los labios y el corazÃ³n calentito.Una historia que reconforta, que nos habla de la superaciÃ³n de los obstÃ¡culos y de la importancia curativa que pueden tener los libros, y las personas, en dichos procesos de sanaciÃ³n. Sometimes you go months and you read, read and read one book after another without really feeling them and you start to lose hope youâ€™re never going to really feel them again. THEN suddenly you read that one book that makes you feel EVERYTHING. Every word hits. This is one of those books. "Per molti amanti della letteratura comincia tutto dall'incontro con un libro che si trasforma in un'esperienza indimenticabile" "E allora speriamo di incontrare ancora tanti bei libri, sia tu che io" disse Tomo "SÃ¬, speriamo" dissi con convinzione"I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki Ã¨ un titolo che tenevo d'occhio da parecchio. Da amante dei libri e della letteratura mi ha subito colpito la trama, che prometteva di perdersi nei meandri della piccola libreria a conduzione famigliare e respirare a pieni polmoni, pagina dopo pagina, il profumo dei libri usati. In parte il libro di Yagisawa ci Ã¨ riuscito, anche se ci sono delle cose da rivedere.Ma di cosa, o chi, parla questo libro? Il romanzo si divide in due parti: nella prima seguiamo la nipote del proprietario della libreria Morisaki, Takako, catapulata sua malgrado nel mondo dei libri e delle librerie. La ragazza, infatti, si ritrova a vivere al primo piano nella suddetta libreria di famiglia, a lavorare come commessa per dare una mano allo zio materno che non vede da parecchi anni ma a cui, da bambina, era molto affezionata. La seconda parte, invece, riguarda piÃ¹ la vita dello zio di Takako, Satoru, anche se Ã¨ la prima che continua a narrarci le vicende che, anche qui suo malgrado, la coinvolgeranno in prima persona.Il romanzo di Satoshi Yagisawa Ã¨ un discreto esordio: tocca con delicatezza, come solo i giapponesi sanno fare, temi come la depressione, l'abbandono, il sentirsi persi e il rimettersi in discussione. Parla di famiglia, di amicizia e anche di amore - che sia per un parente o per una persona amata. Takako, la protagonista venticinquenne, non Ã¨ sempre una persona allegra e simpatica, anzi inizialmente l'ho trovata persino snervante, ma col passare dei capitoli la si conosce meglio e si arriva a comprenderla e ad apprezzarla. Quello che invece mi Ã¨ piaciuto piÃ¹ di tutti Ã¨ Satoru, l'allampanato e strampalato zio proprietario della libreria: goffo, taciturno, Ã¨ uno di quei signori di mezza etÃ  che spiccano sulla folla per il suo abbigliamento strambo. E' un uomo di buon cuore, che ama la sua famiglia e la sua libreria e che, incredibilmente, ha vissuto una vita movimentata. Il rapporto con Takako Ã¨, credo, la cosa che mi Ã¨ piaciuta di piÃ¹.Se devo trovare un difetto a questo libro, direi che Ã¨ frettoloso: certo, in un libro di 140pg non mi aspettavo una grande trama, ma specialmente nella prima parte ho trovato un ritmo troppo veloce, che andava a smorzare e stroncare delle situazioni che, a mio parere, richiedevano piÃ¹ tempo per essere analizzate. Non so se questo Ã¨ dovuto a un numero imposto di pagina che l'autore aveva a disposizione o meno, fatto sta che qualcosa Ã¨ mancato, una introspezione che mi avrebbe aiutato a entrare meglio nelle dimaniche della storia. Peccato...Nel suo complesso I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki Ã¨ un buon libro, di quelli che intrattengono per qualche ora e si leggono in pochi giorni. Non Ã¨ un capolavoro, non Ã¨ indimenticabile, ma Ã¨ anche vero che Ã¨ impossibile non immergersi nelle atmosfere del quartiere Jinbocho, il quartiere dei libri di Tokyo. Una cosa perÃ² devo dirla: malgrado quello che si vede nella copertina italiana e nelle illustrazioni ad ogni inizio capitolo, nel libro non sono presenti gatti. Non so voi che lo avete letto, ma io in parte mi sono sentita illusa! Male male, Feltinelli, male male! u.u "E allora dimmi, cos'hai imparato viaggiando e leggendo?" "Tante cose. Ma a furia di viaggiare e leggere mi convincevo sempre piÃ¹ di non sapere proprio niente. CosÃ¬ Ã¨ la vita. Un dubbio continuo."3.5/5

I received a copy of this book to read in exchange for an honest review via netgalley and the publishers.***AUDIO BOOK VERSION***Days at the Morisaki Bookshop was such a wonderful relaxing book to listen to and delve into audio, and I loved every second. The narrators voice was soothing to listen to and did a great job narrating the book.We follow Takako, who's been dating a colleague, and finds out he's never taken their relationship seriously and is to be married to another woman. Understandably hurt, upset, and embarrassed, Takako resigns from her job and slumps into depression. When her uncle ( whom she hasn't seen in years ) contacts her and offers her a vacation (with some possible shifts) at his used bookshop for the summer, Takako agrees not knowing just how much of a lifeline this will offer her and her future.The characters were lovely in this book, and I loved Takakos' uncle - he was such a sweetheart and great fun to read about. As a lover of books and second-hand books and bookstores, this was a dream to read/listen to and I now wish I too had an eccentric uncle with a second hand book store I too could stay at! This was such a heartwarming book, and I'm so glad to have listened to the audio version.
this book was short, cute, yet so emotionally powerful at some parts. Overall a quite good and fun read.

These cosy, quiet books have such a way of making me love and appreciate life. This book has so many quotes that made me pause to really take them in and contemplate them. I just wish I'd felt a little more emotionally invested in the characters, but other than that I really enjoyed this.

3.5 stars.This brief novel is a loving and tender affirmation of the restorative power of books and reading. It is set in the Jimbocho district of Tokyo which is renowned for its plethora of second hand book shops. The novelâ€™s tone is a combination of melancholy and wistfulness sprinkled with the joy of human connection. The narrative is a bit uneven but succeeds in engaging the reader.

What a lovely comforting read this was. I can say those who love books and want a simple slice of life story with heartwarming and likeable characters, you will enjoy this. Takako Morisaki was heartbroken when her boyfriend said he is getting married to another woman. Unable to cope with the news, she quit her job and lives dreadingly through the days in depressive state. Until her uncle Morisaki called her out of the blue, after years of no contact asking her to move into the second floor of the Morisaki Bookshop. The used bookstore situated in Jimbocho district, a haven of bookstores, a charming street with various bookshops felt like a place that Takako dont think she can fit in. Hesitatingly, she accepted the offer in exchange for a new scene. This is a perfectly cozy book for people who appreciate books. The story is simple, straightforward but also had some deep issues like mental health being addressed in here. To me, it felt like a comforting read, a friend you turn to when u feel like you need a hug. The discovery of books that made you relate to the characters in the stories, the feeling of reading your first ever book and immersed in the plot, the conversations sparked from the book you read with a colleague or friends, the reccommendations you received from others on what books you might like, the desire to understand someone else through the book they read. This charming book had it all and i love this book for this. There is not much plot but i have so much fun reading it, i even shed a few tears towards the end since there is a heartwarming storyline about her uncle and his wife. The love they shared with each other, the loss and grief of losing your precious.

Sweet story about a women, who after finding out the man she's fallen in love with is getting engaged to another woman, discovers herself again at her uncle's bookshop. It's a quiet novel, exploring an area of Japan I've never heard of before that is filled with second hand book stores. It's gentle in its story telling, as we see Takako discovering her own self worth and independence and then using the kindness she's found at the bookshop back onto the people around her.It's similar to a lot of other Japanese literature I've read, but I do really like these slow, quiet character driven stories.

No es un gran lectura, pero es un que me dio mucha paz. No pasa nada extraordinario, pero al mismo tiempo sucede lo mÃ¡s increÃ­ble, el encuentro con los libros.Lo disfrute mucho de una manera muy tranquila.

"Najmanje japanski" japanski roman koji sam proÄitala. PriÄa je sladunjava, likovi nekako ravni, sve je bez neke dubine. Una storia carina, di una ragazza che grazie ai libri ritrova se stessa e il suo equilibrio. Scopre di avere un legame speciale con lo zio, proprietario della libreria. Le varie vicende mi hanno tenuta incollata!

â€œNon Ã¨ sempre facile capire cosa si vuole dalla vita. Anzi, forse lo si capisce a poco a poco, e ci vuole una vita intera...A volte bisogna anche fermarsi. Ã‰ come una sosta in un lungo viaggio. Immagina di aver gettato l'ancora in una piccola baia. Riposerai per un poco e poi la tua nave ripartirÃ .â€I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki Ã¨ un romanzo tipicamente orientale. Ha tutte le caratteristiche che finora ho ritrovato in quasi tutti i romanzi giapponesi che ho letto. La storia Ã¨ ambientata a JinbÅchÅ, il quartiere di Tokyo dove si trovano librerie di ogni genere, un piccolo paradiso per i lettori. Qui si trova anche la libreria Morisaki, una piccola e sgangherata libreria specializzata in letteratura giapponese moderna dove approda suo malgrado Tatako. Tatako Ã¨ una giovane donna che dietro una brutta delusione d'amore, seguita dal licenziamento, si trova a vivere in un limbo di apatia. Passa le sue giornate rinchiusa in casa a dormire, ignara di tutto quello che la circonda. Questo fino a quando lo zio Satoru, che non vede da anni, non la invita a trasferirsi nel piccolo appartamento che si trova proprio sopra la libreria Morisaki. In cambio di vitto e alloggio, Tatako dovrÃ  solo dare una mano in libreria. Inizialmente dubbiosa, Tatako decide di accettare l'offerta e si trasferisce nel magico quartiere di JinbÅchÅ. Ã‰ qui che la vita incolore di Tatako si arricchisce di nuove tonalitÃ , mentre lei riscopre la bellezza della lettura e il rapporto con quello strano zio che ha sempre amato.Ho letto questo breve romanzo in pochissimo tempo, catturata principalmente dalla delicatezza dello stile e da una storia che ha per protagonisti i libri e la lettura. Delicato Ã¨ il termine perfetto per descrivere questo romanzo; se avete letto qualche altro autore giapponese probabilmente avrete familiaritÃ  con questo genere di letteratura fatta di discrezione, eleganza e sensibilitÃ . Non ci sono mai grossi colpi di scena, non Ã¨ mai eccessiva nÃ¨ tanto meno vuole esserlo. Questo romanzo Ã¨ in linea con queste caratteristiche, Ã¨ una storia delicata, caratterizzata da una vena di malinconia che pervade ogni pagina, una storia semplice ma che spinge a riflettere.La storia di Tatako parte sottotono, lei stessa ammette di vivere una vita priva di colore in cui Ã¨ l'apatia a farla da padrone. Quando si trasferisce nella libreria, passa sempre piÃ¹ tempo con lo zio, impara a conoscere i clienti della libreria, si dedica all'esplorazione del quartiere e riscopre la bellezza e il potere dei libri, inizia pian piano a guarire. Il percorso di Tatako Ã¨ la parte principale del romanzo ed Ã¨ molto interessante la sua evoluzione nel corso delle pagine, Ã¨ una storia di rinascita e di riscoperta. Altrettanto interessante Ã¨ la storia dello zio Satoru e della libreria Morisaki che da tre generazioni appartiene alla famiglia. Bellissimo ovviamente tutto il contorno della storia: libri, librerie e lettura. Ã‰ proprio la riscoperta della lettura che permette a Tatako di iniziare ad aprirsi alla vita, di abbandonare la paura e il timore e di lasciarsi finalmente andare. I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki Ã¨ un romanzo lento, semplice sotto certi aspetti, ma che riesce ad affascinare ed emozionare proprio grazie alla sua semplicitÃ .

(3.7) Una historia muy sencilla, rÃ¡pida de leer y que muestra una resumida ese sitio donde se concentran la mayor cantidad de librerÃ­as del mundo. Es tan corto el libro, que vamos desde una depresiÃ³n a un viaje en cuestiÃ³n de pÃ¡ginas (y transcurren muchos dÃ­as de por medio), pero eso es lo que le da la esencia al libro, evita saturar de informaciÃ³n y eventos y se centra en cosas un tanto mÃ¡s relevantes. Sin embargo hay momentos que parece que el libro vuela y nos deja iniciados en ciertos puntos. Me hubiera gustado que profundizara mÃ¡s en el barrio, en sus librerÃ­as y en su gente, pero esa presentaciÃ³n tomÃ³ solo unos cuantos pÃ¡rrafos. Es emotivo a su manera y aunque sÃ­ sentÃ­ que le quedaron faltando mÃ¡s pÃ¡ginas, es la historia que quiso escribir el autor y aÃºn llega a atrapar bastantico.

A bestseller in Japan, winner of a literary prize, and made into a movie, I found this novel very underwhelming. A 25 year old woman quits her job after being dumped by her boyfriend, with whom she works. Depressed and sleeping all day, her uncle, with whom she was once close but has neither seen nor talked to in years, invites her to stay at his used-book bookshop and she does. Alas, for me, nothing about this novel was deep enough. I found it simplistic and superficial. What was interesting was to learn about this part of Japan filled with bookstores and I would have loved to know about those stores, those booksellers, to be in those shops, rather than with the whiny girl.Thanks to Netgalley and Harper Perennial for the ARC.

Classico libro coccola, ode alle librerie e ai libri, che riescono a salvarci nei momenti bui. Il momento riflessione Ã¨ scattato quando la protagonista nel momento di depressione dorme â€˜anche 24 ore filateâ€™ a suo stesso dire, e mi ha ricordato troppo â€˜Sonno profondoâ€™ di Bananina. Ma ai giappo glielo insegnano da piccoli che â€˜wake me up when the bad moment endsâ€™?Comunque al netto niente di che, sono contenta di non averlo comprato (lâ€™ho ascoltato in audiolibro su Storytel, Ã¨ letto molto bene tra lâ€™altro).

Perfetto per una lettura leggera, per un po' di buon umore, per un viaggio mentale dall'altra parte del mondo. L'ingenuitÃ  della protagonista si evolve lentamente senza mai scomparire e si affianca a uno spirito ironico e talvolta tagliente in un mix abbastanza originale. Per il resto, le piccole vicende della trama e l'idillica prospettiva (per molti) di vivere e gestire una libreria sono piÃ¹ che sufficienti per spingere a terminare la lettura; una lettura d'intrattenimento, che lascia tranquillitÃ  e un sorriso, a patto di non chiederle troppo.

This is such a delight to read. The narrator's voice is so distinctive and really relatable. I loved reading about her emotional journey and the people she meets and learns to love. I want to work at the Morisaki Bookshop.
love love love how much i could relate but also someone pls tell me how i can live on top of a bookstore ğŸ˜©

*Big thank you to the publisher for sending me a copy of this to review!*My friend described this book to me as a cuddle under a blanket on an autumn morning and honestly I think she was spot on. This is the perfect cosy little read for this time of year, and if youâ€™re a fan of books about books you'll really enjoy this. Reading it felt like a mini love letter to stories, bookshops, and raiders. It was such a nice little comfort read.I quite liked the writing/translation of this and it felt really easy to sink into and get yourself lost in. I really liked the initial setup of the story and loved the first half of the book as we follow Takako leaving her old life that isnâ€™t serving her very well to go and live in the Morisaki Bookshop. I do think events in this book seem to be a little rushed though and we never really got to ponder or sit with emotions much, which I think would've helped me emotionally invest myself a little bit more and feel that deeper connection I was craving with the characters.The second half of the book felt very different to me, and again quite rushed. It seems to take quite a different direction without really giving us any depth to the actions or emotions of the characters which felt like a shame. I feel like an extra hundred pages or so wouldâ€™ve benefitted this book. It got to the ending and felt very sudden and incomplete, I didnâ€™t quite experience the closure I was craving.Overall and very sweet and cosy read with a promising premise, I just wish it did a bit more with it.

"Itâ€™s funny. No matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life. We live our lives trying to find our way."This book has two distinct parts that offer different vibes. The first segment is like a heartwarming drama, where Takako and Satoru find love and healing in a bookstore, rediscovering themselves and connecting with others on a deeper level through books. The second part jumps ahead in time, focusing more on Satoru's reunion with his long-lost wife, Momoko. While this segment has its moments, I personally preferred the first part because it felt more intimate and focused on character growth. I wished there had been more interactions between Satoru and Takako to see their relationship evolve. Overall, the novel is light on plot but the author beautifully captures the essence of the neighborhood.On a rating scale, I'd give it around 2.5 or 3 stars. It's an easy read that's perfect for passing the time, with a focus on love, books, and the charming ambiance of a bookshop.

This is a quiet book told in two parts. The first follows Takako, a woman whose recent break-up also resulted in quitting her job. She moves into her uncleâ€™s bookstore and develops a love for books. The second focuses on the friendship between Takako and her aunt Momoko, who had left her uncle but recently returned. We learn the reasons for their marital difficulties.I liked the first part more than the second. I enjoyed watching Takako try to heal from emotional wounds by escaping into the world of books. I thought it lost its way a bit in the second part with the abrupt switch to the relationship between Takakoâ€™s aunt and uncle. Still, the book is enjoyable, especially for those who enjoy novels set in bookshops or books about books. 3.5

A book about books is all you need to say.I adore slice-of-life books, and this one was super sweet. The first part was my favorite as we watched our main character slowly fall in love with the joy of reading. The second part's plot lost me a bit, but it was still enjoyable. In the end, I lacked a deep connection with the characters, but I wonder if that's due to this being a translated work. When books are adapted from one language to another, the depth and nuance of the original language language can get lost. Still, a satisfying read that reminded me I love books, despite the string of one-star reads I've had recently.

Am I the only crazy one, or does living in a bookstore sound kool to you as well?The title pretty much speaks to you of all you can expect to know before getting started. The book felt like a novella to me with such a short length. That does not mean you are being compromised in any way. It had just a handful of characters developed through and through with their past, present, habits and lemony life! It's a smooth-paced story of 2 prominent family members that rebuild their once again under the roof of this bookstore. Though there aren't any significant dramatics in here, this is just the kind of book you want to pick on a quiet afternoon and immerse yourself in a Japanese story. Definitely, something I would reread.Thanks, @netgalley @manilla_press @bonnierbooks_uk for the digital ARC. It was short yet heart-touching.Genre: #japanesefiction #contemporary Rating: 4/5 â­ï¸

This was just a really cozy read. A sort of slice-of-life if you will, with a splash of self-discovery and rekindling relationships between uncle and niece. Idk if this is slow-paced but it feels like having that leisurely walk in the park or having a downtime with a book in a coffee shop

3,5â­ï¸Une histoire pleine de douceur, jâ€™ai beaucoup aimÃ© lâ€™ambiance de la premiÃ¨re partie et la relation familiale qui se construit entre Tatako et son oncle mÃªme si jâ€™ai trouvÃ© que le dernier tiers manquait dâ€™approfondissement sur le personnage de Momoko. Jâ€™ai passÃ© un bon moment mais je nâ€™en ressors pas transcendÃ©e non plus !

This is a rather charming tale about the importance of family, and the healing power of books. When Takako's heart is broken, her uncle - whose wife had run away sometime before, offers her a refuge in his bookshop. Initially uninterested in musty old books, she soon picks one of them up and gets lost in the story. I really liked this first part, but then we hit part two. A few years on and Momoko, (the errant wife) returns. This part feels a bit choppy and doesn't flow as well. I don't know if this is in the original text, or to do with the translation.. I did like the story, but found my attention wandered a bit during the second half due to that lack of flow. It looks as though there will be a follow up book which I will certainly be looking out for..*Many thanks to Netgalley and the publishers for a DRC in exchange for an honest opinion.*

Probabilmente non riesco a entrare in sintonia con il modo di pensare e di vedere le cose dei giapponesi: l'ho trovato un libro noioso e banale, con dialoghi infantili e imbarazzanti e personaggi che agiscono in maniera esagerata o sconclusionata.Non sono per niente riuscita a immergermi nel romanzo, troppo sconcertata dallo stile fin troppo semplice e semplicistico, dagli scambi banali tra i personaggi e per quanto sia un romanzo che tratta di tematiche delicate e profonde non Ã¨ riuscito a commuovermi o a emozionarmi. Avrei preferito qualcosa di approfondito, meno veloce e frammentario: succedono un sacco di cose, una dopo l'altra e sembrano piÃ¹ i frammenti di una storia che un vero e proprio racconti. Nemmeno la presenza cosÃ¬ importante dei libri Ã¨ riuscita a conquistarmi: l'ambientazione tranquilla, bucolica e immersa nei libri avrebbe potuto attirarmi con il suo calore famigliare, da amante dei libri, ma i nomi degli autori, i romanzi, mi sono sembrati buttati lÃ¬ e solo uno o due sono stati approfonditi davvero.Ãˆ evidente che i giapponesi abbiano un modo diverso di vedere e vivere le cose e, purtroppo, non combacia con il mio e il romanzo non Ã¨ nemmeno riuscito a trasmettermi appieno queste sensazioni se non il solo fatto che, appunto, non coincidano con le mie.

Okay, so Iâ€™ve got something to say about this book, but Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s gonna make any sense.This starts off so generic that it couldâ€™ve been written by AI. It is straight off the shelf Japanese bookshop YA literature. But then it leaves its tram lines, and not necessarily in a way that I am hoping it would, and yet itâ€™s an improvement. At least it makes you think. So what started off as a 2.5 star ended up as a 4 star.Musings: the language in this book is like Hemingway for under nines. Itâ€™s so simple, not that thatâ€™s bad, because of course, The Old Man and the Sea is one of the greatest books ever written. But it feels much the same as before the coffee gets cold, or the cat who saved books . So it had me wondering, is this a book written for younger readers, is this just the way that Japanese writing translates, is it cultural, or what is going on? Answers on a postcardâ€¦

It was a loveable and beautiful kind of story. Throughout the time I was reading this book, my heart seemed swang into a calm kind of atmosphere. Though i was initially distracted by the poignant of unrequited love, but Takako's movement into Morisaki Bookshop had changed her further life..Throughout this story i found that sometimes we need to escape ourself from where we belong before, and move into somewhere where you could find another story of your life. At the Morisaki Bookshop, there would be a joy, passion, friendship and defenitely a sweet family..Besides, i was stunned by the lines of old second-hand bookshops. Oh gosh i wish i could be there witnessing, smelling and singking me down into the stack of second-hand books. It would be homing for lingering over there..Read this book and feel the wonderful sensation of bookshops filled by second-hand books.Instagram : @hundovert

The friendships and the interactions Takako had with the people in town.7. A lot of good quotes.8. Relatable. I was able to relate to a lot of Takakoâ€™s struggles.Days at the Morisaki Bookshop heavily relies on its characters rather than its plot. If youâ€™re the type of reader who prefers plot driven books, this might not be for you. There were no overly dramatic climax or conflict thatâ€™ll overwhelm you with emotions. It did made me sob a little bit towards the end but that was that. I personally think books like these are a breath of fresh air. One of the reasons why Iâ€™m so drawn to Japanese translated literature lately is because of how easily digestible they are. This book was no different. Iâ€™d highly recommend reading this if youâ€™re looking for a heartwarming book that feels like a warm embrace.

Brutally boring by the end, the mundane manifests well in the first half before taking a sharp dive off the cliff. The main character's arc is complete in part one, making the second segment feel detached and unnecessary. Besides a few thought-provoking quotes, there's nothing to really chew on or remember here.

i liked the gentle, chill, slice-of-life vibes of this story about a young woman reconnecting with her estranged uncle while trying to put her own life back together. part 1 had some truly heartwarming moments between uncle and niece - sadly, part 2 focused on a completely different character and the story lost the charm it had built up in part 1. still a nice, sweet little read.

Tinggal di toko buku tapi ga suka baca? Sayang bangeeet :(Berlatar di Jimbocho, Tokyo, Takako terpaksa tinggal di toko buku bekas milik kerabatnya karena patah hati. Mungkin buat pembaca sepertiku terdengar menyenangkan (tinggal di toko bukunya, of course), tapiâ€¦ Takako sebenernya nggak suka baca buku. Jadi selama tinggal di sana dia tidur melulu :(Buku ini menceritakan latar tempat dengan sangat detail dan menyenangkan, sampai bikin aku googling harga tiket pp Jakarta-Tokyo padahal baru baca 20%. Ternyata, ada satu jalanan legendaris yang isinya toko buku semua namanya Jimbocho! Di Jimbocho juga ada festival buku bekas setiap tahunnya. Jadi siapa yang mau ikut ke Tokyo tahun depan? #loh ğŸ¤£Novel 150 halaman ini terbagi jadi dua bagian, yang pertama Takako dengan kehidupan barunya di toko buku, dan yang kedua tentang kisah kerabatnya dengan mantan istri yang tiba-tiba datang lagi. Cerita yang ringan namun sarat makna, cocok jika kamu butuh refreshing dan nyari bacaan yang ga bikin mikir dua kali.Jadi, apakah Takako jadi suka baca buku? Kenapa sang mantan istri tiba2 kembali? Jangan-jangan, karena dia kehabisan bacaan? ğŸ¤”

A sweet, if not slightly predictable book that ultimately is about healing in different forms. I think I would've probably rated this one higher if I hadn't already read another piece of Japanese literature in September that followed a very similar theme (What You Are Looking For Is In The Library) and that, I think, achieved the message with slightly more style.Still, there's a lot to love here - it's a cosy, easy read that encourages you to think about life differently. I'm not sure it's a book that will necessarily stick with me, but I enjoyed my time with it.
