[ 3.5/5 stars ] "This is your harbor. And your boat is just dropping anchor here for a little while. And after you're well rested, you can set sail again." Takako has an adequate life when her boyfriend announces that he's marrying another woman from the same company where they work. She quits her job and unexpectedly receives a call from a distant uncle Satoru, who asks her to help him at his (family-owned) secondhand bookshop in exchange for living at the second floor of the bookshop.This is such an enchanting read. Set in Jimbocho - the world's greatest neighborhood for secondhand bookshops - the story, permeated by old and used books, is a feast for any bookworm.Books establish a connection between characters, often painting a life-changing experience. Satoru is a weird and unconventional uncle whose wife left him years ago. And through books, Takako learns a different side of him, feeling the closeness that they once shared.With accessible prose and soft flow of time, the plot isn't driven by momentum, instead a quiet tenderness will keep one company. This novel is about life's purpose and self-discovery, about finding one's own way.In only 150 pages, DAYS AT THE MORISAKI BOOKSHOP is a heartfelt touch of life's small joys, just the right kind of hopeful/positivity for these difficult times. One will find some comfort in it and feel all the charm of secondhand books. Quite a meditative read.[ I received a complimentary copy from the publisher -  Harper Perennial . All opinions are my own ]

â€œThe festival was such a success that it surprised me. Book lovers of all ages flocked to the neighborhood. Maybe because it was a once-a-year event, but the turnout went far beyond my expectations. You could feel the energy on Yasukuni and Sakura Streets. This old sepia-toned neighborhood of secondhand bookshops was now buzzing with activity before noon. It was a pretty spectacular sight.Our Morisaki Bookshop joined in too, of course.â€- Takako

Un libriccino delicato sul potere salvifico dei libri, dei clssici in particolare (giapponesi, in questo caso).Tatako ha subito una forte delusione, perchÃ© ha scoperto che l'uomo con cui aveva una storia - e che lavorava nella sua stessa azienda - Ã¨ fidanzato con un'altra ragazza, che sta per sposare. Decide cosÃ¬ di abbandonare il lavoro e cade in una crisi profonda, finchÃ© non viene invitata dallo zio ad andare a vivere sopra alla sua libreria, la libreria Morisaki, nel quartiere Jinbocho, il quartiere delle librerie. Una favola dolce e un po' nostalgica, con la sua atmosfera tutta giapponese.

Ini adalah kisah menyentuh tentang seorang wanita muda yang menemukan kegembiraan dari membaca setelah melewati masa-masa sulit. Buku ini sederhana yang membahas tentang buku, hubungan, keluarga, dan komunitas. Buku ini menyenangkan, mudah dibaca, terutama saat liburan atau ketika sedang membutuhkan kehangatan, kenyamanan. Saya merasa buku ini menarik karena ditulis dengan baik dan menarik. Secara keseluruhan, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop adalah bacaan yang menarik dan mengesankan. I love this book so muchhhğŸ’“
â€œI donâ€™t think it really matters whether you know a lot about books or not. That said, I donâ€™t know that much myself. But I think what matters far more with a book is how it affects you.â€

â€œNo matter where I went, no matter who I was with, if I could be honest with myself, then that was where I belonged.â€

â€œThe act of seeing is no small thing. To see something is to be possessed by it. Sometimes it carries off a part of you, sometimes itâ€™s your whole soul.â€

â€œItâ€™s funny. No matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life. We live our lives trying to find our way.â€

â€œDonâ€™t be afraid to love someone. When you fall in love, I want you to fall in love all the way. Even if it ends in heartache, please donâ€™t live a lonely life without love. Iâ€™ve been so worried that because of what happened youâ€™ll give up on falling in love. Love is wonderful. I donâ€™t want you to forget that. Those memories of people you love, they never disappear. They go on warming your heart as long as you live.â€

Days at the Morisaki Bookshop carries a theme that generally entices readers. The plot is set in a cosy secondhand bookshop that is run by a middle aged man who has a sweet personality and attracts an eccentric crowd. Satoshi Yagishawa pens a simple plot, divided into two parts. Our protagonist is a young woman who is wronged by her boyfriend and reluctantly seeks refuge at her uncleâ€™s bookstore. Takako and her uncle once shared a close bond but years of distance weakened the relationship. And so Takako arrives at Morisaki bookshop carrying little to no expectations about how her life would change. The first part of the novel explores Takako familiarising with her uncle and rekindling her love for reading. In this quaint part of the district where rows and rows of bookstores are lined, she regains a part of herself that she had long given up on. Together with her uncle and his friends, Takako eases back into a joyful life, devouring books at breakneck speed. She makes unexpected friendships too. The second part introduces a new character. Momoko, wife of Takakoâ€™s uncle who returns after disappearing for a few years. It is here that the story starts to fall apart. What already seemed like an ordinary story starts slipping away from us. All the characters lacked depth making the story only superficially interesting. I also couldnâ€™t help but find the cover a bit misleading too. But the feel good aspect that comes with stories revolving around bookstores does exist a bit. Overall, I did feel a bit disappointed because I went in expecting a lot. Another example of bookstagramâ€™s hype not living up to my expectations.

2,5 â­ Siendo sincera, me aburriÃ³ un poco. La primera parte que gira en torno a la librerÃ­a es bonita, simple, pero muy bonita. De la mitad en adelante no entendÃ­ hacia donde iba, perdÃ­ el enganche y ya querÃ­a terminar el libro. PensÃ© que iba a sacar mÃ¡s reflexiones del libro y que iba a ser un "feel good", pero no pasÃ³, lamentablemente. De todas maneras estÃ¡ bueno si uno necesita una lectura ligera para pasar el rato.

After her boyfriend tells her that heâ€™s been seeing someone else and that heâ€™s going to get married, Takako quits her job and falls into deep depression. She winds up moving above her uncleâ€™s secondhand bookshop located in Jimbocho, Tokyoâ€™s famous book district. Although she has no interest in books at first, she gradually develops a passion for reading.Besides Takako and her uncle we also meet a variety of quirky characters. I really enjoyed spending time with them. I thought I was going to lose interest during the second half of the book as we learn more about the uncle, but the story quickly drew me in again as Takako spends time at the neighborhood coffee shop, takes a trip to a mountain inn, and helps her uncle deal with the events from his past. It felt like a sentimental soap opera at times, but it was also a love letter to the many pleasures of reading. I really enjoyed it. I might be a little biased though as this book brought back many fond memories of my time in Japan, not just my visits to Jimbocho, but also traveling by train, visits to coffee shops, and mountain hikes. â€œItâ€™s funny. No matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life. We live our lives trying to find our way. Itâ€™s like that SantÅka Taneda poem, the one that goes, â€˜On and on, in and in, and still the blue-green mountains.â€™â€

No matter where you go, or how many books you read, you still know nothing, you havenâ€™t seen anything. And thatâ€™s life. We live our lives trying to find our way.Attached above is one among many of my favorite passages in the book. Crazy that I have 71 highlights when the book is only 150 pages. And it just... makes me feel so seen. Highly recommended if you're looking for a short and comforting book!

If youâ€™re trying to get back into reading or if youâ€™re looking for something gentle to see you through, this is definitely the book to read. Almost translucent in its simplicity and beauty. I fell in love, in life, in everything. Felt like the warmth of a cup of tea spreading into all-around comfort.

This book was lent by my good friend, Sonia Shenoy, and reading the paperback was a pleasure IndeedA short book , in the typical Japanese style of writing which I have come to recognise more and more, about youth, loneliness, urge to seek companionship and life in general, and how books influence us, in varying degrees and ways.

THIS BOOK HIT ME IN MY FEELS.For all my indigo besties, please read this. It made me think of all my memories working at a bookstore and experiencing that kind of connection with books and other book lovers. I absolutely recommend this book, what a fab time

so this was a miss for me? which i didnâ€™t except after all the hype Iâ€™ve seen Itâ€™s not a bad book and I didnâ€™t dislike it but I didnâ€™t really find anything to likethe comments I keep seeing are about the emotions this book evokes. To me, everything was flat. the characters are really dry and one dimensional. they are so passive, dead reactions and expression. It was like they were just a written role, even the things they said I felt were said without feeling. It was like the author was trying to throw in these meaningful quotes and reflections on life without any depth or build up or emotional connection. the story switched up and was choppy and too distracted, all the supposed â€œhealingâ€ and â€œtransformationâ€ was so hasty and underwhelming the writing was also too too simple for my likingIâ€™m really not sure if the faults Iâ€™ve pointed out are because of original writing or translation?? It could definitely be that all the meaning and emotions were lost in translation but Iâ€™m not sure all I can say is it felt rehearsed. like it was trying to give this heartfelt healing drama vibe, yet it ended up being dull and plain. sorry not sorry. nonetheless, some moments were nice and I liked some lines

3.5 starsHarmless and inoffensive, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is another entries to the gradually growing collection of translated Japanese 'cozy' literature, similar to Before the Coffee Gets Cold. While I appreciate the gentleness and the intimacy of a single location, human-focused stories, I can't help but feel something is lost in translationâ€”the unadorned prose feels superficial, and the emotional delivery is more Hallmark greeting cards rather than something more heartfelt and profound, as if the English vocabulary only managed to convey the straightforward, surface level action, without contextualizing the nuance in the subtext.While I'm happy to see contemporary Japanese literature making wave in the market, I don't think for me reading stories like this in English is the best option. Even though I can't read Japanese, I'll be curious to re-read this in its Chinese iteration to see if I feel any different!

The book in question had been heavily promoted and had a lot of buzz surrounding it, leading me to have high expectations. However, upon reading it, I found it to be rather underwhelming. The writing style, which was quite personal, may appeal to some readers, but I found it to be rather dull and lacking in nuance. It took me a significant amount of time to finish the book, as I found it difficult to read for extended periods due to the monotony of the writing style. It felt as though I was reading the diary of someone who had little experience with crafting a compelling narrative. While I can understand how some readers may enjoy this style of writing, it simply did not resonate with me. Overall, I found the book to be quite disappointing and would not recommend it to others unless they are fans of this particular writing style.

Life is full of ups and downs, yet occasionally a person really needs support from someone.Takako was a young woman who had lost her job and been dumped by her lover. She slept as much of the day as she could because it made her so miserable. Her uncle then summoned her to his home one day. She was hesitant at first, but visiting Morisaki Bookshop changed her life. Has she truly discovered the purpose of life?The book is a simple story about family, friends, love, books, book lovers, relationship and community. The scene where uncle Satoru encourages Takako and gives her self-assurance that she can accomplish anything is my favourite. I also really liked the friendship that Takako, Tomo, and Takano had. I was saddened by Aunt Momoko's tragic and hidden narrative, but I was furious when she ran away. The happy, uncomplicated conclusion satisfied me.

Judul : Days at the Morisaki BookshopAuthor: Satoshi YagisawaTebal : 160 halPenerbit : Harper PerennialTerbit : 4 Juli 2023ISBN : 9780063278677Ada pepatah : Don't Judge a Book by It's Cover. Tapi kalo ngeliat cover yang secakep ini, apalagi tentang buku, kaya me manggil-manggil buat dibeli ğŸ˜†Tapi ternyata kisahnya bagus dan sederhana mengalir aja bacanya. Takako yang berusia 25 tahun mengalami patah hati dan kekecewaan yang dalam setelah mengetahui kalau pacarnya, Hideaki yang sudah setahun bersamanya; ternyata telah bertunangan dengan wanita lain yang sama-sama sekantor dengan-nya.Si Takako yang sangat mencintai Hideaki sangat terpuruk dan memutuskan berhenti dari kantor tersebut. Ibu Takako yang mengetahui hal ini menghubungi Paman Takako yang bernama Satoru. Agar segera membantu Takako keluar dari keterpurukan nya.Satoru pria berusia sekitar 40 tahun menjalankan bisnis toko buku bekas dari generasi ke generasi. Takako pun di bujuk dan dimintai tolong oleh Satoru untuk menjadi Penjaga Toko Buku Morisaki. Akhirnya Takako bersedia dan ia tinggal di lantai 2 toko buku bekas tersebut.Takako yang sama sekali tidak suka membaca awalnya, diperkenalkan buku yang bakalan ia suka oleh Paman nya. Benar saja, Takako segera tenggelam dalam bacaan yang direkomendasikan Satoru paman-nya.Ceritanya tidak tentang buku saja, tapi lebih ke kisah hidup Satoru yang ditinggalkan Momoko istrinya, ada lagi teman baru Takako di daerah tersebut bernama Tomo dan Takano. Juga Wada seorang pembaca yang sering berkunjung ke toko buku Morisaki.Bagaimana Takako bangkit dari keterpurukan dan kekecewaan nya? alurnya cukup cepat dan mengalir. rasanya Endingnya kaya masi Ada yang kurang dan ga terlalu berkesan. Tapi untuk bacaan santai dan sekali duduk buku ini boleh dicoba:)3.8 â­â­â­â­ dari ku :)

A Tokyo esiste un quartiere chiamato "Jinbocho" totalmente dedicato alle librerie e alle case editrici, in cui si susseguono vetrine di volumi nuovi e di seconda mano, praticamente il paradiso dei lettori.Tatako, una ragazza di venticinque anni, si troverÃ  a vivere nel primo piano della libreria di suo zio Satoru Morisaki, dopo aver perso lavoro e fidanzato (quest'ultimo la lascia per sposare un'altra). CosÃ¬, tra cataste pericolanti di libri, Tatako verrÃ  conquistata dal mondo dei lettori, conoscerÃ  i clienti della libreria e scoprirÃ  per quale motivo sua zia Momoko, moglie di Satoru, Ã¨ sparita abbandonando il marito senza spiegazioni...Un romanzo semplice ma estremamente evocativo, capace di trasportare il lettore in un'ambientazione perfetta per gli amanti dei libri e della letteratura giapponese.La storia si svolge in maniera piuttosto lineare, senza grandi colpi di scena, Ã¨ adatta ai lettori che desiderano una lettura pacata e scorrevole da leggere in un soffio.Nel romanzo sono citati tanti autori nipponici purtroppo ancora poco conosciuti da noi, inoltre ho apprezzato molto come l'autore abbia fatto avvicinare la protagonista al mondo dei libri e della letteratura, generando una crescita ed una rinascita in Tatako."I miei giorni alla libreria Morisaki" Ã¨ un romanzo breve che racconta con delicatezza la capacitÃ  dei libri di rigenerare e salvare dalle delusioni della vita.ğŸ“•pp_ 160

â€œMis dÃ­as en la librerÃ­a Morisakiâ€ de Satoshi Yagisawa es una novela japonesa que trata sobre la vida de Takako, una joven de 25 aÃ±os que tras una desilusiÃ³n amorosa renuncia a su trabajo y, en medio de la tristeza en la que se ve sumergida, acepta la invitaciÃ³n de su tÃ­o Satoru de vivir en la planta alta de su librerÃ­a mientras trabaja para Ã©l con jornada de medio tiempo.En el desarrollo de la novela conoceremos no sÃ³lo a Takako y Satoru, sino tambiÃ©n al seÃ±or Sabu, Hideaki, Momoko, Tomo, Takano, Wada Akira, entre otros mÃ¡s. La librerÃ­a se encuentra situada en el barrio JinbÅchÅ, este barrio realmente existe en Tokio, son calles y calles especializadas en libros, ademÃ¡s de librerÃ­as hay tiendas de antigÃ¼edades, restaurantes y editoriales de manga. Volviendo a la ficciÃ³n, el nombre completo de la librerÃ­a del seÃ±or Satoru es â€œLibrerÃ­a especializada en literatura moderna - Morisakiâ€.La novela estÃ¡ llena de sorpresas, a pesar de que sÃ³lo cuenta con 160 pÃ¡ginas. Bland, boring -and surprisingly lacking in books, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is a trite and cliched (supposed) â€œjourneyâ€ of a young girl â€œfindingâ€ herself.Hmmmâ€¦Seriously, what is it with this latest literary trend of writing books that lack not only depth and originality, but are so unbearably â€œsweetâ€ they donâ€™t even border on the sickly side, they nigh on surpass it -bring me the bucket please! Now you may think Iâ€™m being harsh (and perhaps I am), but Iâ€™m so fed up of being disappointed by books that claim to be about one thing (in this instance about the â€œhealing power of booksâ€), but are instead, a far too twee and morally questionable (for my liking) cast of simplified (dare I say heavily parodied) characters, whoâ€™s lives donâ€™t revolve -or even evolve, around or because of books, but instead are self absorbed, and heavily influenced (though I guess this is written by a man *queue the â€œnot all menâ€ brigade*) by the patriarchy "Are you cooking him some of the dishes I taught you?â€ Or even better â€œIf my wife tried that, I'd knock her down.â€, who are far more focused on how to please their partners, or getting into romantic relationships, than the powerful art of storytelling.Gorgeous cover, gruellingly dull read.1 star

"Donâ€™t be afraid to love someone. When you fall in love, I want you to fall in love all the way. Even if it ends in heartache, please donâ€™t live a lonely life without love. Days at the Morisaki Bookshop is a heartwarming tale of love, family and self-discovery. Takako perfectly portrayed what it means to be a woman in her twenties figuring out life and its purpose in between the complexities of it all. The bond between Takako and her uncle, Satoru, was very heartening and as someone who believes in the power of reconnecting with the good of the past, this tale is one of many examples that I adoreâ€”more so with the familial aspect that comes along with it.The storytelling was very much uncomplicated and child's play for beginners with an intent to take a dip in the genre of translated fiction, as well as for advanced readers alike. But despite the simplicity of its writing, the characters felt very well fleshed out and each were very complex with their own individual characteristics. All incorporated very well with a bona fide build up of the atmosphere that surrounds these interesting cast of characters. The more you read, the more you felt as if you were in the Morisaki Bookshop itself, browsing, perhaps overhearing Takako and Satoru's conversation or perhaps theirs with the regular customers. Or perhaps you started imagining the ambience of a cafÃ© with the strong scents of coffee beans hitting your nostrils and the sound of pages turning, rapidly or leisurely. Oh, to be in such a world right now!Like many other translated fictions I have been privileged enough to read and experience, Days at the Morisaki Bookshop prompted such intricate questions and reminders into our existence in the world and our purpose to not just ourselves but also to others. There were simply so many parts in the book as well as conversations that I resonated with in both the present and the past. I related to Takako so much when she was detailing her experience with depression after her life had wholly turned around from what she once knew. The feeling of not being able to even get up from our beds, the energy we once had simply disappeared into thin air, hard to grasp nor see that all one could do with their whole being was to sleep. I was brought back to May to early of August last year when I was deep within my own depression. Unable to get up, missing classes because I simply felt like the world around me was crumbling at every step. But with the right support and coping mechanismsâ€”in this case for us, it's booksâ€”you could overcome such battles one baby step at a time. You don't need to go about life so quickly without processing whatever grief you find yourself feeling to show the world you are strong. You are stronger when you acknowledge the pain and the chaos that comes after a hurricane and moving forward, you'll find yourself to be filled with more empathy towards yourself and towards others. And I think Takako's character truly showed that in the second part of the book.All in all, it was a meaningful read to me and I'm so glad to have broken out of my procrastination to finally finish this after weeks of picking it up and absorbing word-by-word into me slowly but surely. So many lessons in such a short tale and yet I cannot leave you without recommending this immensely beautiful book for you to read in your own time. I cannot wait to hear your thoughts on this one, dear readers.My love and gratitude goes out to Definitely Books by Pansing Distribution as always for sending me such great titles as this for me to pour my honest thoughts on for others to consume. Thank you thank you thank you!â˜† Where you can find me! â˜†

Tiene unas frases muy lindas y me gusta esa sensaciÃ³n de calma y contemplaciÃ³n de la primera mitad, pero la segunda me tuvo menos enganchado; siento que hubo menos profundidad en las situaciones, en esta parte es donde se concentran frases y actitudes sexistas, que por mÃ¡s que tenga contemplado que es JapÃ³n no puedo dejar de verlas como algo molesto, sobre todo porque recuerdan a interacciones familiares muy recurrentes. Hay un abrazo por ahÃ­ y me pareciÃ³ muy significativo teniendo en cuenta lo poquÃ­simo que pueden llegar a tener contacto fÃ­sico, sobre todo con las diferencias de generaciones. (Recomiendo ver "Tokyo idols" porque allÃ­ exponen cÃ³mo con la globalizaciÃ³n y otros aspectos las generaciones menores crecen con una idea muy distinta de algo tan sencillo como un apretÃ³n de manos, pero para generaciones mayores eso puede ser algo tan Ã­ntimo como sexual. El documental es terrible pero arroja muchas consideraciones interesantes. No es el caso de este libro, pero el abrazo tiene mucho mÃ¡s peso considerando estas cosas, antes que como lector occidental que hasta nos saludamos de abrazo y/o beso.) TambiÃ©n tengo algo contra esos inicios de libros o cuentos que comienzan vendiendo muchÃ­simo algunos sucesos, por ejemplo "el suceso que vivÃ­ fue lo mÃ¡s aterrador del mundo", "lo que les voy a contar me cambiÃ³ la vida para siempre", y al final no me parece que funcione mÃ¡s que para el arranque. Como recurso retÃ³rico estÃ¡ padre porque puede hacer que nos quedemos con aquello que mÃ¡s nos resuene como aquello realmente significativo en la vida de alguien: si es el viaje, una ruptura, una nueva manera de ver los comienzos, una nueva actitud frente a los mayores, una idea mÃ¡s clara del futuro y todo eso que deja el libro, pero al mismo tiempo siento una pequeÃ±Ã­sima necesidad de conclusiÃ³n de la voz narrativa, en la que me digan quÃ© fue lo que hizo cambiar como tanto dice que cambiÃ³. No porque no pueda extraer yo o cualquier lector (porque, como dije, creo que tiene que ver con que cada uno se queda con lo que mÃ¡s le impacta) sino porque la exageraciÃ³n con que se vende la historia como algo revelador y realmente cambiante no siempre resuena enteramente. Mucha expectativa para unas lecciones no tan meritorias.SÃ­ me gustÃ³, aunque parezca que no. Son quisquillosidades mÃ­as al leer esas figuras retÃ³ricas y las frases levemente problemÃ¡ticas.Adoro esa mirada del espacio en la que el clima, las flores, los colores de las hojas y la cantidad de nubes en el cielo sean parte importante de estar en el momento y en el dÃ­a. Adoro la calma y todo lo de la primera mitad en cuanto a historia.

Â«â€”No es cuestiÃ³n de ser expertos o novatos. Si lo plantea asÃ­, ni siquiera yo lo soy tanto. Lo importante es sentir emociones al toparse con un libro.Â»
Mis dÃ­as en la librerÃ­a Morisaki es un libro de ficcion contemporanea que abre la bilogia de la LibrerÃ­a Morisaki escrita por el autor japones Satoshi Yagisawa. Durante el libro conocemos a Tatako, una mujer japonesa que llega al barrio de Jinbocho, en Tokio, despues de que se entera que el chico con el que salia la estaba engaÃ±ando con otra persona. En la libreria conoce al dueÃ±o de la tienda, su tio Satoru quien le ofrece vivir con ella en un pequeÃ±o departamento situado arriba de la libreria con la condicion de que ella se encargue de la librerÃ­a mientras el no este.
Trama: 9/10
Llevo mucho tiempo queriendo leer mas literatura asiatica y este libro parecia ser el indicado. Una de las cosas que me gusta es que me pude ver reflejado con Tatako porque ella no era al principio del libro una lectora y se rehusaba a leer los ejemplares que tenia su tio, y me gusto ver como durante el transcurso comenzo a sentirse cada vez mas intrigada por estos hasta que se convirtio en lectora. Algo quiza si que no me gusto es que siento que paso mucho en tan poco, quiza por la longitud del libro.
Personajes: 9/10
Tatako me parecio un personaje un poco molesto al inicio del libro pero conforme vas leyendo comienzas a entenderla y a sentirte identificado con ella. Satoru tambien me gusta como mantiene esa energia a pesar de su edad y la manera en la que Tatako lo describe a lo largo del libro hace que te termines de encariÃ±ar con el. Tambien me gusto que hay personajes que si bien, no son tan importantes en la trama, te alegras al ver que tienen algunas escena o algun dialogo.
Final: 7/10
Lastimosamente el final no fue tanto de mi agrado, quiza por lo mismo de que siento que hay algunas cosas que no terminan de cerrar y que de tanto que ocurrio no sientes que en realidad sea un final. Quiza y es algo que se soluciona con el segundo libro pero si fuera un libro autoconclusivo si hubiera sentido que le faltaban paginas o algo asi.3.5 estrellas (teodiogr)

El libro tiene una prosa sencilla y fluida, lo que lo hace fÃ¡cil de leer y seguir. La mayorÃ­a de los personajes son bastante unidimensionales, ademÃ¡s, la trama es lenta por momentos, lo que puede resultar aburrido para algunos lectores. Aunque hay algunos momentos emotivos y conmovedores, en general, la historia no logrÃ³ engancharme realmente.A pesar de estos defectos, la historia tiene algunas virtudes destacables, como la descripciÃ³n detallada y vÃ­vida de la librerÃ­a y los libros que contiene. El autor transmite claramente su amor por los libros y su importancia en nuestras vidas. AdemÃ¡s, la historia se desarrolla en un ambiente relajado y acogedor que hace que la lectura sea agradable.Si eres un amante de las historias lentas y tranquilas sobre la vida cotidiana y estÃ¡s buscando una historia ligera y reconfortante, te recomiendo darle una oportunidad. Sin embargo, si buscas una trama mÃ¡s compleja y personajes mÃ¡s profundos, esta novela podrÃ­a no satisfacer tus expectativas. Por estas razones, le doy una calificaciÃ³n de 3/5.

ValoraciÃ³n exacta: 4/10Mis dÃ­as en la librerÃ­a Morisaki puede considerarse como una novela liviana, entretenida, sin demasiadas pretensiones. Si solo miramos los resultados, puede considerÃ¡rsela asÃ­â€¦ pero no creo que haya sido esa la intenciÃ³n de Yagisawa, para nada. Mas bien creo que es una novela que intenta ser profunda y tener un mensaje de Ã­ndole moral, pero que fracasa estrepitosamente en el intento. Tanto fracasa, que la mejor manera de disfrutarla, sin sentirse demasiado decepcionado, es olvidarse del mensaje que intenta dar, y leerla solo como un entretenimiento liviano, sin darle mÃ¡s vueltas.EstÃ¡ dividida en dos partes muy marcadas: la primera, que es la que da nombre al libro, relata como Takako, tras romper con su novio (y renunciar al trabajo que compartÃ­a con Ã©ste, por ese motivo), acepta la invitaciÃ³n de su tÃ­o Saturo a mudarse con Ã©l y darle una mano en la atenciÃ³n de la librerÃ­a. En la segunda parte, ella ya no trabaja en la librerÃ­a, pero vuelve a vincularse con su tÃ­o para ayudarlo a resolver una situaciÃ³n de su presente, pero muy relacionada con su pasado sentimental.La verdad que el libro me decepcionÃ³. Sin embargo, es probable que buena parte de esa decepciÃ³n tenga mÃ¡s que ver con lo que el libro promete en su sinopsis de contratapa (Â¿para quÃ© las sigo leyendo?, me pregunto. Cuando no te mienten, te spoilean partes fundamentales de la trama, arruinÃ¡ndotela) que con lo que el libro es en sÃ­. Una gran promesa incumplida, asÃ­ definirÃ­a la historia. â€œEntre discusiones cada vez mÃ¡s apasionantes sobre la literatura japonesa moderna [â€¦] Takako irÃ¡ descubriendo poco a poco una forma de comunicarse y de relacionarse que parte de los libros para llegar al corazÃ³nâ€. Eso dice la sinopsis. Â¡CuÃ¡ntas mentiras en una sola frase! Por empezar, esas â€œdiscusiones cada vez mÃ¡s apasionantes sobre la literatura japonesa modernaâ€ no existen: en la novela se mencionan un puÃ±ado de autores, pero sin describrirlos para nada, y, en lo que respecta a libros, solo hace menciÃ³n superficialmente de tres, de los cuales al menos uno estoy bastante seguro de que no existe y fue inventado para la novela. TambiÃ©n lo de ir â€œdescubriendo poco a pocoâ€ es falaz: el cambio en Takako es abrupto, y se debe mucho mÃ¡s a su tÃ­o que a cualquier lectura que haya tenido.Como dije al comienzo, el libro intenta dar un mensaje mÃ¡s o menos profundo sobre la importancia de comunicarse, decir las cosas de frente y abrir tu corazÃ³n. La verdad que todo eso me resultÃ³ bastante indiferente. AquÃ­ creo que puede influir el tema cultural. Seguramente para los japoneses el planteamiento puede ser mÃ¡s significativo, pero para los latinos, que no tenemos demasiado problema en gritarnos las cosas a la cara sin ningÃºn tapujo, la parquedad y falta de diÃ¡logo que muestran los personajes todo el tiempo -y en especial Takako- termina resultando irritante. Es muy difÃ­cil empatizar con ella, y eso hace que el mensaje se diluya completamente.En fin, el libro me decepcionÃ³. HabÃ­a comenzado bien. De hecho, la premisa base (la chica herida que va a vivir con su tÃ­o un tanto excÃ©ntrico y enamorado de los libros y gracias a eso logra dar un giro a su vida) me resultaba muy llamativa. Sumado a las discusiones literarias, esperaba encontrarme con algo similar a Persona normal, la novela de Benito Taibo que leÃ­ hace algunos aÃ±os y me encantÃ³: un â€œlibro sobre librosâ€ que me deleitara con una trama de amor familiar al mismo tiempo que me incentivaba a adentrarme mÃ¡s en el mundo de la literatura nipona y descubrir nuevos autores. Pero nada de eso se cumpliÃ³.

A young woman's dick-of-a-boyfriend casually drops the bombshell that he's getting married to someone else. She finds refuge in her quirky uncle's second-hand bookshop. Sounds like this should be charming and delightful, right?Sadly, no. I found writing, plot and characters wooden and clunky. It feels contrived and the way characters acted could be quite jarring. Takako, the main character, irritated me for the first half by being too self-centred while her uncle, Satoru, threw out too many twee life lessons. The writing feels very simplistic and bland. I'm giving this the benefit of the doubt by assuming some of this might be down to the translation? I remember reading some sentences and thinking 'Is that the word you really meant?' It's a short read so I did see it through to the end and the final chapter did at least see me sympathise with Satoru and his wife's story which is why I haven't rated this 1 star :(

li este livro em conjunto com uma amiga como prenda de anos para outra amiga e adorei a experiÃªncia. decidimos oferecer o livro com os nossos comentÃ¡rios anotados, portanto vou escrever aqui a review final que deixei na Ãºltima pÃ¡gina <3no geral gostei bastante! a histÃ³ria foi muito cativante. acima de tudo foi super confortante e todo o capÃ­tulo em que ela estÃ¡ na livraria foi relatable em certos aspetos. gostava de ter uma experiÃªncia destas. o tio Ã© sÃ³ incrÃ­vel e deixou-me com ainda mais vontade de ter uma livraria no futuro.jÃ¡ a parte da tia deixou-me um pouco desiludida. talvez seja por ela ser um pouco estranha e dar-me mÃ¡s vibes metade do tempo. o facto de ela ser muito fechada tambÃ©m fez com que, quando ela se abriu, eu tivesse zero empatia com a situaÃ§Ã£o.o character development da takako foi muito bonito e a prÃ³pria relaÃ§Ã£o dela com os tios foi interessante. principalmente as diferenÃ§as entre elas. dou 3,5â­ï¸

Piccoli libriccini, pagine bianche in cui sono riportati pensieri, follie, emozioni travolgenti e inespugnabili, possono a volte insegnare tante cose. Il mio amore per la letteratura si Ã¨ intensificato negli anni a tal punto da conciliare tale amore come una sorta di stile di vita: senza i libri la mia anima sarebbe priva di consistenza. Inutile. Opaca come un vetro rotto e sporco e di solito il mio tempo libero lo trascorro a leggere, cibarmi di opere di autori conosciuti e non che danno colore, senso a tutto questo. Fu cosÃ¬ che, quando seppi della pubblicazione di questo piccolo libriccino, non ci pensai due volte a entrare nellâ€™androne gigantesco di questa polverosa libreria di Tokyo e gettare ombre complesse e incrociate sul pavimento di legno scricchiolante, e me ne stetti lÃ¬, assieme alla protagonista, a bocca aperta, ad osservare gigantesche pile di romanzi che forse non leggerÃ² mai. Rassegnata, non sono cosÃ¬ ingenua a credere che da qui a quanto starÃ² in vita potrÃ² leggere tutti i romanzi esistenti sulla faccia della terra. Si puÃ² leggere, che Ã¨ un arte straordinaria e meravigliosa. E poi si puÃ² vivere di libri, che Ã¨ quello per cui do un senso a ogni cosa, giorno dopo giorno. Leggo di tutto, a volte cose inutili altre volte importanti e difficili. Quella di questa lettura Ã¨ una tematica piuttosto cara alla me lettrice, ai lettori, agli amanti della carta. Ed estrapolarla da una finestra virtuale dallâ€™aria luminosa e vaporosa, ascoltando la voce gracchiante del suo autore risuonare nelle pareti della mia coscienza, Ã¨ un brivido di piacere che attraversÃ² il mio corpo e non se ne andÃ² tanto facilmente. Nemmeno ora che ripongo queste poche righe. Nemmeno ora che constato come effettivamente ho letto storie piÃ¹ belle che parlano di libri, di librerie, hanno lasciato un segno profondo nella sabbia del tempo. LÃ¬ sono rimaste e mai piÃ¹ evaporate. Ma mi affascina sempre essere condotta in questi tipi di luoghi, attratta come da una calamita e godo cosÃ¬ tanto di tutto questo non per il piacere in sÃ©, quanto per la felicitÃ  che comportano certi momenti.Uscire da questa storia non mi ha trasformata o cambiata. Ma Ã¨ stato come vivere una specie di fiaba, molto carina ma non indimenticabile, che ho seguito con ogni mossa, vivendo e respirando. Un timido scrittore giapponese scrisse dei versi ispirandosi alla sua esperienza personale di letteratura, componendo una musica semplice che non vanno al di lÃ  della concretezza, ma in un certo senso trovano un posto dentro di lui. Non dentro di me, che non si Ã¨ sentita legata allâ€™anima della sua storia, ma coinvolta da ciÃ² che Takako dovrÃ  affrontare, che solo alla fine darÃ  sfogo allâ€™emozioni che inconsapevolmente ha cercato, ha rincorso. Un assetto romantico di comprendere se stessi. Si fluttua in una piscina di incertezza, al confine della nostra coscienza, con in sottofondo lâ€™inesorabile fragore del mondo.Rappresentazione di due realtÃ  opposte: luce e ombra, speranza e disperazione, riso e tristezza, fiducia e solitudine, opera che evoca qualcosa di speciale. Un altro tempo, un altro luogo, o una particolare dimensione della mente in cui io mi sono persa completamente. Piacevolissima compagnia che altri non Ã¨ che un esame della sua coscienza in cui si arriverÃ  a un punto in cui non si sa piÃ¹ cosa sia vero o sbagliato. Ci si perderÃ  nel labirinto del tempo, dei ricordi di cui Ã¨ prigioniera e, vagando in una grande casa che Ã¨ una specie di labirinto, cercherÃ  quella stanza particolare dove passato e futuro formano una corda ininterrotta e infinita. Uno spazio in cui Ã¨ sospeso un codice che nessuno ha mai saputo decifrare, un accordo che nessuno ha mai ascoltato.

Mostly set around a womanâ€™s relationship with her aunt and uncle, this translated Japanese novella is a cozy, year-round story set in a bookshop. I will probably read this story again someday just for the lovely, cozy vibes.

A cast of one dimensional characters. No plot really. I mean there is one, but the fact that it is about character development, yet there is no significant character development, makes it appears simplistic. Also it seems to throw these kind of reflective quotes here n there to sound deep (I know this may be harsh but that's how it felt).Â Not enjoyable. And too simple for my taste.

These cozy books donâ€™t work for me cause I tend to find them cheesy, sappy, and cliche. Iâ€™m convinced that itâ€™s much harder to write happy, heartwarming stories than it is to write sad stories, and thatâ€™s why these books usually fail to move me.Iâ€™ll stick to romance when I want an actual heartwarming story.

This was a short, lovely read. I enjoyed the evolution of the main character and her relationship with her uncle. There were some unrealistic elements and clunky dialogue, but since this is a translated book, I decided to take that in stride. I came into it expecting a light, uplifting story, and I was not disappointed.

I liked the beginning of the the book but about 60 pages in the story was over, at least the story I signed up for. After this the plot completely changes from what is written on the back of the book2,5*

A tiny family owned bookshop on Jimbocho Book Town, hidden away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo's busy city life. Cozy cafes, wondering it's streets as you try to find meaning in your life, and learn to find whimsy in ordinary life. Just my cup of tea.This gentle novel transported me and gave me a big, warm hug.
